Reviews.title: It Works...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
OK, it arrived on time, but that is sort of an issue. When I purchased this product, Amazon guaranteed delivery on Sunday Feb. 6, 2022. On the 6th, I woke up to an email that it would be delayed until Monday the 7th. No problem, we had a blizzard and people have been digging out. BUT, it was delivered on Sunday and just left outside, in the freezing cold and snow, without me knowing or expecting it was going to happen. Luckily, a friend stopped in for five minutes, and by coincidence that's when the package was left in the cold and snow, so it wasn't there when he came up the porch, but it was there when he went down and my package got to me safely. The seller bears no responsibility for this, as it was fulfilled by Amazon, but for some reason, Amazon doesn't let us write reviews for the customer service, so here it is. You can do better, Amazon.

As for the product itself, it's not really as bad as my "stars" would suggest. It arrived in what appears to be brand new packaging. I can't find any evidence that the anti-static bag was ever opened before. I installed it in my aging Dell Inspiron 3700 (with an i5-8400, and 12GB of RAM) hooked it all up, turned it on, and after about 5 minutes of some installation process (at which time there WAS video) my screen automatically reverted to the display settings it had prior to the install, and it works just fine. I installed Nvidia GeForce and, after one more driver update it was over. The entire process was from start to finish was less than 20 minutes.

This was the first time I have ever installed a GPU, and I can only assume that that is EXACTLY how it is supposed to work. As for the value for money, NO GPU has a good value to money ratio. Crypto-miners and the pandemic have seen to that.

As for gaming, this just is NOT a card built to plays today's most advanced games. I got this card because PGA 2K21 can only track one profile at a time, so two people with two profiles need two copies of the game to track their stats in co-op. Now, my aging Dell could manage about 25 FPS in "potato mode," a number that made it unplayable. With this card, on low settings (one step up from potato mode), this card and the i5 deliver 90FPS steadily at 1080p quality.

The problem there, is that 2K21 is really "The Golf Club 3" with 2K's marketing slapped on the box. As such, the entire install from Steam was just 6.6GB. And as every modern gamer knows, the 5-15GB game file size was lost to any game above the 'indie" classification when the games went 4K. Which means that the game would have to still be in potato mode if 4K textures even existed in the files for processing.

The only other "modern" game I have on the Dell is Kerbal Space Program. And that, with low settings turned on, and the FPS locked to 80, this card and the i5 can get maintain a steady 60 in the assembly buildings and launchpad, and dropped into the 40 FPS range during the launches I tested. But that is normal. KSP can make even monster PC's cry for mercy if the user launches a big enough ship. The limitation there is far more CPU dependent than GPU dependent as the game tries to simulate physics, heat, and gravity calculations on hundreds of individual parts simultaneously.

As for video streaming, honestly, I don't see very much improvement over the streaming quality of just the i5, but there is no LESS quality to the streaming, and that's what matters. My monitor is a 32" 1440p, with a 144 Hz refresh rate.

I do, however, have a couple of issues with this card. On the product description page, there is clearly a picture of the various output I expected to find on this card. And if I remember right that picture had a display port, an HDMI port, a 24 pin DVI port, and a VGA port (I might be wrong about the VGA port). The card that arrived at my house, does NOT have either a VGA port or a display port. So, if your monitor has either of those, BUYER BEWARE!!! I was only ever going to use the HDMI port, so I'm not too fussed.

My bigger issue is the plastic shroud on the GPU itself. The card doesn't cover the same amount of area that the plastic shroud does, so I have several square inches of exposed plastic shroud inside my PC, acting as a "bowl" to catch any dust flying around. And while the Dell has a paper filter the covers the main air intake, and a sort of cone directing the CPU exhaust directly out into the room and that has kept the amount of dust inside my case to a minimum. But now there is the GPU fan sourcing air from an unfiltered area, and just exhausting the air inside the case. So, ALL bets are off as to how this plays out in the remaining life left in my aging Dell.

That is just BAD design all the way around. It uses more material than is strictly needed meaning the manufacturer is paying more than is strictly necessary for each card manufactured, and it CAN'T be good for the PC to have an actual dust catcher inside a machine that you work hard to keep dust free. And I can PROMISE the manufacturer, that if my aging Dell suddenly dies six weeks from now, I know EXACTLY who I will blame. I won't get a refund, but THEY won't get a return customer.

And for that reason, ultimately, I will give this GPU a 3-star rating with a serious "BUYER BEWARE" due to the misleading product photos, as well as the poorly designed fan shroud.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
This graphics card works well in our limited-power mini-tower.

It'd be perfect for our needs if it had a 2nd HDMI port, but a simple adapter cable did the trick since one of the two monitors we hooked up had that necessary DVI port as well as its HDMI port.

I can recommend this card as a good performance/value graphics card for your limited-power computer.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text: Received it in a timely manner from Amazon, that part went well. Had to do a little digging in the Nvidia web site to find the correct updated drivers. The drivers are there you just need to do more than a simple search for current drivers for newer cards. This is a fairly old video card ( even though new) and the original drivers that were installed have been well and truly superseded. Updated the drivers, BUT before I could take advantage of all of the cards capabilities I Had to create a Nvidia account. That really SUCKS! The card works just fine as is, and since I'm not going to use it for any heavy duty gaming I guess I'll just have to live with it as is... As I write this I'm reminded of the fact that if I want to register the card I'm going to have to create an account any way, looks like the jokes on me! Darned if I do and darned if I don't...

Reviews.title: Works With Dell 8900
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2021
Reviews.text: Review for: MAXSUN GEFORCE GT 1030 2GB GDDR5 GPU. Product arrived on time with typical packaging in bubble wrap bag with no damage or other issues. Got this during the Black Friday sales; good price. Bought this GPU for a DELL XPS 8900 i7-6700K Skylake CPU (yes, for 8900 NOT 8920 or 8930 or any other 89xx) and I have to say It was a bit risky thinking the GPU wouldn't take, but it did. It fits perfect and doesn't overlap on the 2240 M.2 SATA SSD (See photos). After installation NVIDIA program recognized the GPU and updated the software automatically. I'm not using this for games but I am using DreamWeaver, Photoshop, Illustrator etc... as well as ZOOM for online college courses and a couple of other graphics demanding programs. I didn't have to mess with or update the BIOS, it was simply plug and play. Temperature wise it stays pretty cool. The only modification was having to exchange the original GPU bracket with this 1030 bracket. It worked out fine. (See Photos)

Reviews.title: Pretty good. Has room for improvement on cooling in particular, but not a bad option.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2022
Reviews.text:
I got this because I feel like the 3060 Ti strikes a pretty good balance between a lot of things -- including the oft-forgotten questions of power usage and heat production. Performance-wise people point to the 3070 and say go ahead and spend the extra, but I do want to point out that the 3060 Ti generally outperforms the previous generation's 2080 Super in most things (and barely does any worse at all in the things it doesn't beat it at.) Zotac's offering is a good price and seems to be a reliable choice which was my biggest consideration right now (I want this thing to last a long time.)

The only complaints I do have are about the cooling. The heatsink's design is actually really good and I don't have any complaints about the heatsink itself. It's worth noting that many videocards have the fins oriented vertically instead of horizontally, so so air can flow through them out the back of the case (thus meaning those cards can only recycle air and rely on the case to have good airflow.) This one is properly oriented horizontally, so *some* air can go out. I emphasize some because of two things. First, it's open on both sides, so of course some air still goes back to the case out the inside part and gets recycled -- but of course GPU fans rarely have high static pressure anyway, so blocking that side doesn't actually improve cooling (mind you, my case has pretty decent airflow, so it may do better to cover the inside end in worse cases than mine.) I do also think the fans should be tilted just ever so slightly to actually make the air go a direction other than straight down into the heatsink, but I don't know if any videocard manufacturer has ever thought of this yet.

I also noticed the thermal paste apparently wasn't ideal or at least wasn't ideally placed (maybe too much I think.) I took it apart under the assumption they used the usual really cheap stuff many GPUs have, but it looked like it maybe wasn't actually terrible. I can't be sure what it is from just its appearance alone, but it did seem to be a bit lower viscosity than ideal, so maybe not the highest grade. When I changed the thermal paste its temperatures dropped by approximately 3C from the top and close to that at idle (and thermal paste is less about maximum temperature and more just about minimizing heat dissipation latency, so when you see a notable drop in temperature that means a lot more than it may seem.) It may just have been too much on there as there was definitely quite a lot and it was hard to clean, so that is a distinct possibility and could potentially even save them money if it's just a matter of reducing it ever so slightly.

There was one definitely bad choice on this card I'm unhappy about though -- and this is the biggest reason I knocked one star off from the max (the other stuff is pretty typical of GPUs in general probably.) For some reason they stuck little aluminum tags with their name and logo on the fans themselves with a heavy foam tape. This just seems like a really dumb choice no matter how I look at it. For one, it adds extra mass to the fans, which reduces their efficiency and lifetime. For another, apparently the process varies because on mine one of the tags was off center and looked kind of bad (plus was probably even worse for the lifetime of the fan as it would make it run fairly unevently, affecting its long-term life.) Again, my goal is for this thing to last, and if the fans die out on me not that far down the road that's definitely not lasting. Since they used a thick foam tape though, it's hard to get them completely off (I had to pry very very carefully and slowly to not risk damaging the fans in the process.) Actually, this may have had some effect on the temperature in itself since the fans now probably run that tiny bit more efficiently (but doesn't account for a full 3C.)

Now, that said, I've seen reviews saying this card is loud. I don't know if they've revised this model or what, but I did not feel like the fans were loud at all. I get more noise from the other fans in my case definitely (mind you, it's not a silent case by any means, but I never feel like the noise is bad now.) Certainly a lot better than the awful stock cooler that came with my CPU (that thing started to reach hurricane levels under load I swear.) Also, the GPU seems to actually stay a very good temperature. The reviews saying the fans were loud said it would run > 70C, but, in fact, I'm seeing a maximum of around 61C or so now (slightly higher before) with normal gaming keeping it at about 57C or so roughly the majority of the time (versus 60C before I redid the thermal compound.) It only got up to around 61C or so when I saw GPU usage go way up to about 85% (normally it's 50-60 in most games but some hit the mid 70s or so. That 85% was only for a short duration.) I have a very high confidence now that this card will last me a very long time short of something unexpected and extreme happening. Overall I'd call it a good design other than those few points I mentioned earlier.

Reviews.title: Pretty Good, and no, the noise is not annoying.

The minimun and maximun i get when i am not doing gaming is 32° and 40°. When i am playing triple A games (God of war, Spiderman, etc) i get 75° as minimun and 88° as maximun. But, the performance of this card is just amazing, I love it. In God of War (all in ultra, at 1080p without dlss) i get more than 70+ fps, but if i change graphics at high, i get more than 100+ fps.

Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2022

Reviews.title: Definitely hot
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2022
Reviews.text: It does run hot but I figured out why. In the zotac firestorm software there is a gpu temp target. It sits way too high. Unlock the link between the temp target and the power percent and you can bring down the temp target. I set mine to 75 and it runs much cooler now by ramping up the fan speed sooner rather than later. This gpu has a massive thermal mass. Making the fans need to come on sooner to overcome the hysteresis caused by the temp sensors and thermal mass.

Reviews.title: Get some more case fans
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2022
Reviews.text:
This GPU has a very 'open' heat sink design meaning a lot of the air that cools the GPU may end up back in the case and recycled. To get good performance, you need good circulation of air through the case.

When I first installed the GPU I had two case fans; One intake fan in the front and one exhaust fan behind the CPU. In this configuration, the GPU was running at >80c and throttling down to <750MHz. Now that I've installed a couple more intake fans in the front, I get a reliable >1700MHz performance at <65c. That leaves plenty of room for tuning/overclocking above that.

If you are spending >$1000 on a GPU, you can afford $10 for case fans to unlock that performance.

Save your money, get an rtx3070 or rtx 3080. The rtx 3090 isn't worth the additional $500-$800.

Considering returning, and downgrading( upgrading to a card with no frame lag) to an rtx 3080

Reviews.title: UPDATED (Arrived with issues, still waiting to hear back from support)
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2022
Reviews.text:
UPDATE: Support did get back to me and in the process of getting information about the RAM modules, they are not both working and I have the advertised 16gb. I've updated the rating to four stars because support was still quite slow to get back to me and there wasn't a quicker, more direct way to contact them. The computer works as intended now and the damaged case isn't the manufacturer's fault.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Arrived with some cosmetic damage to the top front of the case. This isn't the seller/manufacturer's fault but certainly worth noting. It runs fine and has a lot of performance for the money. The reason it gets one star is because Windows is only reporting 8gb of RAM, and it's supposed to have 16. I checked to make sure both sticks are seated but still only showing 8gb. I contacted support through the only method possible - a form on their website. I've heard nothing back besides the automated reply. It's been five days. I am also unable to register it because it seems like the model is discontinued and the model isn't an option on the registration form. Overall the computer is fine, notwithstanding defective RAM. However, five days and no reply after I've received a defective product is unacceptable and I cannot recommend this computer based on that alone.

Reviews.title: Thankful for Amazon Payments

Reviews.title: Great card, great value
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2022
Reviews.text: I got this earlier in the year (2022)when it was a little more expensive, but I still don’t regret it. I upgraded from the Rtx 2060 super and I can really tell the difference in frames at 1440p on my 165hz monitor, it’s been about six months now and I haven’t had any problems. But I will say that It can get kinda loud, I don’t notice most of the time bc it’s only in intense gaming and the game is usually loud too so unless I take my headset off I don’t notice it. But it may be an issue if you have other people in the room trying to sleep or what not.it’s fans have an option to stay off tho when using low power so that helps a lot to offset the noise issue. But anyway, this papacy all of my games at any setting I want and after using it for six months I can safely recommend this card to anyone, especially at its current price of ~600$ right now

My case and case fans are cool and quiet, so not sure why its revving so loud, the game is not a tough game to run. Doesnt really bother me at all, just can't believe people are saying it has no noise.

Reviews.title: Powerful but bulky.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2022
Reviews.text: While it may not be as ultra powerful as the 3090 Ti, it still packs a punch! The only complaint that I have, is that it is way too bulky and big for my custom gaming desktop. I am not sure why but it just takes up so much space! Not to mention that you have to use the PSU cables, just to plug it up. (I am not really a fan of GPUs that require you to plug something up to it) It's asking price is pretty debatable too and they are becoming harder to find online! Hopefully when the 4000 Ti graphic card series is finally released to the public, ZOTAC will take notes and make their GPUS a little smaller, a certain percentage cheaper and will not require us to have to use PSU cables. I highly recommend this GPU over the now common 3060 Ti!

Reviews.title: Great if you can get it at/below msrp
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2022
Reviews.text:
I bought this when there happened to be a sale and it was below msrp even at the zotac website (I got it for ~770 before tax, and on Zotacs website they sell it at ~850).

It works great. Before this I was running my computer on integrated graphics with a ryzen 5 5600g, and that worked great by itself for the games I play but I wanted to be able to stream or render 3d models without suffering, and never worry about lag in games.

A 2080 is good enough for what I wanted, and a 3070 ti like this is MORE than enough. If its below msrp, or even /slightly/ above, its definitely worth buying this card.

Now that my cpu doesn't have to run graphics at the same time as other things (for reference it used to say in task manager my graphics was at 40% when I was using integrated even just basic website idling, now idle its barely at 5%), I have no doubt my computer will run way better and I'll had a better time gaming.

Tldr: Amazing card, but its better if you can buy it at a sale price as everything is hella inflated.

Reviews.title: Great card, no complaints
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2022
Reviews.text: What can I say? It’s a 3070TI. It’s a beast of a card, especially for the price I paid ($750). It runs all my games on 1440p at 120+ FPS on the highest settings. I do see some people saying this card is loud, but I have not ran into that issue at all. Even after gaming for 8+ hours straight this card was at around 68c and the fans were barely audible. It’s worth mentioning that my tower sits on my desk next to my monitors, so if the noise was bad, I would definitely hear it. I don’t have any complaints about this card. It’s exactly what I hoped it would be, and it has exceeded my expectations on performance.

Reviews.title: Good value considering the current ridiculous graphics card market
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
I got this for my wife. She uses her i7-12700K based machine mostly for rendering still images, so this is just what I thought was an adequate card which is below the steep part of the price performance curve. After building the machine I ran the Passmark tests and was surprised to find that this has substantially better 2D performance (1255) than my RTX3070 (943), 3D performance for the 1660 Super was 14,168 compared to 24,787 for the RTX3070. Considering she mostly needs 2D and I mostly need 3D I guess we both got what we needed.

While testing and installing software I ran a 3440x1440 144Hz monitor on Display Port and a 3840x2160 TV on HDMI and both looked good. No signs of the card running out of performance or bandwidth. On an old GTX980 the fast monitor gave color fringes until I turned it down to 60Hz.

I wouldn't hesitate to buy this card again for any normal PC. Unless you are playing very high resolution 3D games it should do everything you want.

Reviews.title: Exceptional Performance from small card!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2021
Reviews.text: My goal was being able to play the newer games on my Dell, more specifically, FC4. I had bought the RX 570 which did a great job, but for some reason, it was extremely noisy. It made a loud whirring sound every time I played the game. The other games I've played, Fallout 3 and 4, Crysis, the card didn't make those horrible sounds. Realizing the cost of gpu's are rapidly escalating, I checked out the GTX 1660 Super. I checked it with games-debate and it was superior to the RX 570. The frame rates are incredible! Also, a BIG plus was the small size of the card. I already had an 8 pin adapter to plug it in and it installed super easy and ran like a dream. The temperature of the card runs within the norm and has made an incredible difference in game play. I highly, VERY highly recommend this card! It's a good price for the card and it delivers exceptional performance if you're unable to get the higher end gpu's. It's worth the price!

Reviews.title: Good at the price for typically Ultra settings
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2020
Reviews.text: I am using a Ryzen 5 1600 paired with a 660ti so this upgrade for me was very substantial and really the cheapest way to break into ultra settings with 60+ FPS (usually above 75fps even in modern games like borderlands 3) which is perfect since I have a 1080p monitor with a 75hz refresh rate. Anything stronger than this card would yield better results but, would probably be bottlnecked past a rtx 2060 or 2060s which is the next price bracket above this card. So this really works well with the 2016 released Ryzen 5 I’m using. I think at the $249 I paid in about June of 2020 was very fair and I have been very happy with it overall. If you have more money get an RTX 2060s but at $250 or slightly under this is a great option. This card is small so it’ll fit in to many cases, not quite a low profile but smaller than some single fan designs I’ve seen. For its size it also weighs more than I’d expect it to eluding to a nice heat sink. Overall the thermals are not bad and I have overclocked it utilizing the OC feature on MSI afterburner and now my clock speed is around 1700 and boosts up a little past 2000 which is actually pretty great for just using the stock cooler. It isn’t very loud and I do have an open case design so I would be able to quickly tell. I like that the card is simple because some look obnoxious but, I would have liked even just a simple clean backplate especially since I’ve seen cheaper 1650 cards with backplates for $100 less than this card.

The RGB looks amazing but, the stand is not necessary. The motherboard more than supports this hefty card. JUST BUY IT!!!!

Reviews.title: Triple Screen 4K Gaming, Very fast card, much better value than new 3090 or 3090ti as of July '22
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2022
Reviews.text: As others have reviewed this card did had slight coil whine when I first got it. PowerColor on the box recommends at least a 950W PSU and I only had an EVGA 850W Gold so I upgraded to a EVGA 1000W Platinum PSU and the coil whine went away and is even quieter than my wife's PowerColor 6800XT. This is a heavy card so I highly recommend using the included GPU bracket to prevent card sag long term and PCIE x16 socket stress. I play triple screen 4k games, (75% of 8k resolution) and stock card settings on COD Vanguard with ultra settings, triple 4k, FSR set to ultra quality, I get 85-90 fps with dips down to 75 so it keeps my 70hz 4k monitors well fed. Flight Simulator 2020 gets 22-25fps on high settings triple 4k so enough to fly but not ultra smooth, such a non optimized game. Far cry 5 triple is 45-55 fps on ultra so a bit lower. I should note these numbers are with Smart Access Memory enabled as well. Also for context my CPU is a Ryzen 9 - 5950x. I have found that AMD's eyefinity surround works much better and more consistent than nVidia surround. I did have an EVGA 3070 and had soo many issues with surround, like disabling monitors in windows after leaving surround mode. I like eyefinity's ability to go into surround only when playing games as this is my work-from-home PC so for premier pro, affinity publisher and the like I prefer the normal Windows scaling experience. This card pulls around 289W on stock settings and temps are decent (70c), enabling extra watts via +20% power makes this card pull 346 watts and gets very warm, (82c-85c). My case is a Thermaltake View 71 (Large Case) and my CPU is on a 360 radiator so there is decent airflow with my additional 5 case fans. I did buy a damaged box card (saved $150 buying from Amazon Warehouse) and the card has been great so far.

Reviews.title: Great Card, solid offering from team red
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
Reviews.text:
I’ve had the card a few months now. There’s a few things that have stood out to me.

I purchased before the price drops of all the current cards at time of writing, do I feel like I should have waited? Yeah, but I don’t feel like I was ripped off. This card blows away anything I throw at it.

Red devil has a lead to allow the card to the motherboards rgb header, so it matches the motherboard rgb colors for an easier rgb matching.

Team red offers a top end gpu with stable drivers, I’ve had less issues with the programs I work with compared to my previous gpu (2080 Super). I don’t use any driver software such as adrenaline or GeForce now, so that doesn’t make a huge difference to me.

Overall, great card. Quiet, fast, handles everything I throw at it at 4K or 1440 ultra wide.

Reviews.title: Incredible Performance
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2022
Reviews.text: Aside from the amazing performance, this cards construction is impeccable. It's built like a tank. The back plate and fan shroud are heavy metal and worthy of being considered artwork. I wont even get into the benchmark numbers other than to say they are impressive. Top tier to say the least. My build consists of an x570 Aorus Xtreme rev 1.1, Ryzen 9 5950x, Aorus 360mm aio, G.Skill F43600C14-16GTZN 32gb, Sabrent 1tb Rocket 4 Plus, EVGA supernova 1000w Gold+ PSU, and of course Powercolor Red Devil 6950 xt. I was pleasantly surprised to be able to use my uphere graphics card bracket as it supports the card very well and adds much needed rgb under the card instead of sudden darkness. Even under extreme loads for sustained periods of time the thermal solution keeps things cool and quiet.All this is wrapped up in a Phantexs Full tower case. It's a work station but I play games on it as well. Now I can do both even better. The one and only thing I wish they had done was put the rgb Red Devil Logo on the front edge like they did on the 5700xt. Otherwise my review is 100% 5 star. I highly recommend this product to anyone that wants top of the line performance and great value.

Reviews.title: Thank you for the payment plans Amazon !
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2022
Reviews.text: Coming from an rx6700xt, I was looking at an RX 6800. Or XT. With prices going down, that looked like my next card. I really wanted to stay all AMD. Then, this came along. I’m a sucker for strix cards and had one been available(with a payment plan) I would have stayed true to Lisa Su. Instead, I went with the competition. I’m still rocking a 5800x and Crosshair DTX motherboard. This combo is incredible together. You do have to fiddle with temps and find the right overclock. I finally found a stable 2010mhz overclock and that nets me some serious frames. I honestly feel bad not going AMD this time around cause they make a great GPU nowadays. Between this and an rx 6800xt, with either choice you won’t be disappointed. Having access to ray tracing finally is nice. This GPU is beautifully made. I’m not sad in the slightest with this card. Of course Nvidia being Nvidia quietly released the 12gb version. That’s the only part about Nvidia that I dislike. You buy say, an RTX 3070. Then, Nvidia releases a tI version of the 3070, making your 3070 suddenly seem like a bad idea and wish you had just waited. That’s another reason why I wait so long after a GPU launch. I want to wait and see how many variations get to the market before I decide. Even getting this 3080, when we’re months from the new gen cards from both companies seems unwise. But, it will be at least a year or more before we know the full GPU landscape and I want1440p 100 FPS+, now.

Reviews.title: Great! The second time around...
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
Hi I'm Ben and this is my story..

TLDR; I ordered this GPU and was so excited when I got it overnight for FREE. Then I opened the package and realized that someone literally took the frame off of a 3080 and put a EVGA 2070 Super inside and re-packaged it in the 3080 box................ I was really mad. I decided to give Amazon a second chance because of their overnight shipping and sent the first product back and for a refund. The second overnight shipment was a success and was a perfectly brand new ASUS 3080 that runs great! Amazon got my package and issued my refund in about a weeks time as well, so no complaints there.

Just beware that there may be GPU swappers out there pulling things like this.

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

This card has no problem running any of them, even at the high refresh rate of my monitors. And it streams to other devices at 4k seemlessly. But if you're hoping to game in 4k, even with just one monitor, you might want a little more power. If you don't already have a motherboard with a PCIE 4.0 slot available, consider purchasing one with this card, or else it will lose a significant amount of its potential. The fans run at full speed during gaming, but so far, this card has not run any hotter than it would streaming a movie.

Reviews.title: low-grade tech support -
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2022
Reviews.text:
in short, i have worked in tech support for over 20 years. due to declining health issues aka "shaking" and "vision", I no longer build systems. Sadly, my previous system was from 2009 and is able to run windows 10 professional. that stands for quality of the product; however, my income and credit has declined so i had to make compromises. end result, choose Zotac for a gaming type system ... not really for gaming but for content creation and 4K monitors. Yes, the system does run 3x 32 inch 4K monitors without any hiccup. It is whisper quiet so that is nice. The M.2 drive has quick access so summary that is the reason I got it. the root problem with Zotac, in comparision to other companies like Dell, is "service." if you own an infinity you will get better service than if you own a "toyota" .... just saying. no disrespect to toyota ... we own one and this is our third toyota but pc service regardless of the company is key to me.

now to the complaint, you call their tech support and it doesn't state ... "please hold" .... like Dell you are the fifth person in line. Please hold or you leave your number for callback. What Zotac does is "beep" and expects you to know that the beep means leave a message. The second issue is after 5x tries to get tech support, i sent in an email. i get an email back that i should call. well i called, got sales, who couldn't transfer me to an agent. then i called customer service who said they are "away" from their desk. while on the call with customer service, tech support chimed in. Then the tech support guy didn't even ask for my "order" so that he could get the "specs" of the system. the company i work for, we use "phone number" searches, email searches, order searches, etc. to find their specs. Then, as most companies, verify the customer. then listen to the issue and pull up the specs of the system and then prompt remote access to the computer. he did remote access which i expected and had closed private information before hand. this is normal process at my company and they are fine with that process ... no complaints here. he looked up the motherboard but couldn't find the drivers for the wifi and the bluetooth PCI card that was attached. had you looked up the order and saw the details then downloading drivers is easy. end result, is the device doesn't have Windows 11 drivers ... but the issue isn't his fault for not having the drivers BUT not knowing what devices are installed in the system is "low grade" tech support. he should have access to the order info, look up the details, then down load the drivers. Even the windows 11 upgrade didn't find them. my work around was to use a 3rd party wifi device that I already owned and wifi now works. I don't use bluetooth because my mouse and keyboard are wired along with my wired speakers.

i did get a warranty, but my issue is "how" did he "assume" that the wifi card isn't defective. re-seating the card is standard troubleshooting so i understand that process. I didn't have time to do that on the call. however, he didn't even have the "drivers" or know what card was installed.

just word of caution ... they are cheaper but "cheaper" in the tech support area too. A similar Dell XPS system would cost $5000+ to get the same performance as the AMD and that's beyond my means having taken a 30% cut in pay to just get a job. A job is better income than "unemployment" ... everything else seems to work fine. I will note their "documentation" is less than favorable ... doesn't state what motherboard is installed on the system specs nor the details of what drives can be installed inside the chassis. for myself, my career goals are changing from database to developer and i need a system with large displays and no video lag so the game PC achieved my objective. everything is "usb" so using the "hubs" works for me. however, money and credit provided, I would have gotten a "Digital Storm" computer with far better service, hardware, and expandability than even Dell offers. for the now, a good gaming system if that's your need and NO didn't include a keyboard or mouse as the picture shows. i already use ergo keyboard and mouse anyway but that was mis-leading.

DAY 2
Note, I am A+ computer repair certified for last 20 years been doing repair. in short, reseated the Wifi / bluetooth card and still does not work. rebooted and search for drivers and still not found. update is that I have emailed the company for a callback on their "registered" phone number to avoid scammers. i will update and see if they will correct this issue and just send me a replace wifi / blue card.

WEEK 2

The wifi and the bluetooth still DO NOT work. I installed a 3rd party USB card for expansion and had a few issues but that's a different story. now all the external hard drives with a faster connection than the SATA drives and I still don't have a returned instruction on how to attach the SATA drives. I did a little research on MSI website which is the mother board Type ... MSI MPG X570 ... basically a "mini" gaming motherboard. No SLI option on this motherboard in case anyone needs to know. for myself, 12GB of video RAM is for content creation so for my objective, it is fine. I will be trying to re-connect with Zotac support again regarding wifi and the bluetooth. If there is still no help, everything is working but I'll never buy from them again. With the ever increasing prices and shipping interruptions, I will just keep the system and add a second wifi card and go back thru my boxes of computer stuff for my bluetooth adapter. I really don't use bluetooth so no big issue but the principal is EVERYTHING should work out of the box.

Update for Week 2

To date, the wifi doesn't work, hard to get hold of the tech support now that I am working a part-time job and they are NOT 24/7 hours at the convenience of the customer. They state the wifi/bluetooth card is fine which is INCORRECT. card has been res-eated and still not found. the models given don't match the models on the zotac site therefore what drivers do i install. in short, submitting CEO complaint to see if i can get adjustment. put in the 2nd USB card and using my personal wifi connection and found my bluetooth dongle and it now works. in short - don't buy from here unless you are short on cash like me. if i had to re-do and no finance issues, means buy from Dell or HP with a good warranty and ability to get a human 24/7.

Week 3 or something
Thought I had right address for CEO complaint and got letter returned. Due to all the shipping hiccups, I am keeping the system. Wi-Fi Bluetooth card yanked and using 2x usb hub cards with external Bluetooth and Wi-Fi. All works and and I have both usb and usb-c drives attached external thru hub.

SUMMARY- if you want “Service” this NOT the company to buy from.

Reviews.title: Great gaming card but a mixed bag dealing with Amazon
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
First and foremost, this graphics card is great. The only thing I have some issues with is VR but everything else runs butter smooth. My original card was a GTX 1660 ti and was a really good card for the price but I started running into issues of modern games not running so great and constantly lowering quality of certain games. VR of course was always playable but I could definitely see the downgrade of my previous card so it wasn't the card itself but was my hunger for better gaming. The card gets a 5 star from me, it does exactly what it's supposed to do. My only small complaint is that the fans can get a bit loud from time to time but that isn't a deal breaker for me.

The only reason I'm giving this 3 stars is having to deal with Amazon. My first hiccup was my original purchase was "lost" in the mail. I say "lost" because I don't believe my package ever was placed on a logistic vehicle and after about a week they finally decided to send a new unit. I did receive the replacement within one to two days so that wasn't a huge deal. I think me wanting the graphics card as soon as the site had said was what got me frustrated. When ordering the card there was a promotion for receiving three games after three business days of the card shipping and after the card is installed into your PC. I've been in contact with several support agents and at this point I'm just being ignored or passed along to another department. The promotion ended August 1st, I believe, but even before that the product page of the card I purchased stopped working completely so when I tried talking with a support agent they would have no way of looking it up. Luckily I screen grabbed the promotion listing with a bit of information linking the purchased card to the promotion but every time I mention this they tell me I'll get an email from a different department that "specializes" in the issue I'm having. I wanted to make this review strictly about the graphics card but had no avenue to review the product and the company separately, at least not from my knowledge of searching. I even contacted both Nvidia and Zotac and both companies said around the same thing that Amazon is responsible for game codes. I contacted those two companies because Amazon told me one of them was responsible for game codes which I later learned was just a dance to get me to go away.

So to summarize, I love the graphics card. Games look great, run extremely well and I'm overall very happy with my purchase. Amazon hubris has finally reached a tipping point where service is declining and support has been outsourced to other countries while not giving them the resources necessary to actually help customers. I've been an Amazon customer for over 15 years and have always been a cheerleader for the company but with all my shipping issues, customer support chats and calls the company is turning into just another faceless online store that cares very little about the people that got them where they are. I hope it gets better with the company because there was a time where Prime was an essential part of my life but am now questioning if it's worth it now. So Zotac RTX 3080 good, Amazon bad.

Reviews.title: Research 3080 VRAM thermals / GDDR6x thermals
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2021
Reviews.text:
This card is incredible. It runs modern tripleA games @ max settings with ease. Mine runs Sekiro @2550/1440p 144hz Max settings at 42celsius, massive improvement from my 1060GTX 6gb. My GTX ran the same game @ 1920/1080p 60hz medium settings and stayed 82celsius basically the whole time the game was open. I bought this card within 10% of MSRP to future-proof my build so that hopefully I won't even have to look at the GPU market for another 5 years. My only complaint is the current state of the GPU market (Aug2021).

(Edit 08/29/2021)
I really hate to drop my review of this product to 3-stars because the seller is amazing and provided great customer service, I even found a friend in him. I'm dropping the rating because I just starting running newer titles on ultra that actually use a good % of the VRAM and wow, the manufacturer of this product either put little or no effort into the VRAM module thermals. I haven't opened the product to look at the thermal pad contact points yet *and may even not -so as not to void the warranty* but wow, I am disappointed in Zotac for letting this leave their factory. Its possible I just received an unlucky card but based on everything I've read online about GDDR6X thermal issues this is seems to be a wide-spread problem among just about every card that uses GDDR6X. The card works wonderfully for casual gaming but I can't actually use this card for stable Modern-Ultra-setting because the VRAM gets so hot that the GPU starts thermal-throttling @69C to prevent the VRAM from going over 82C. It's becoming clear that I'll have to either RMA this product and hope I get one with better thermal protection for the VRAM or "go under the hood" myself (void the warranty) and remove the cheap pads and place good ones. Very unfortunate.

Reviews.title: Follow these steps for best oob performance. Best 1080p card at it's price point.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2022
Reviews.text:
Flick the switch on the top of the card to the left so it's set to the "overclock" profile
Copy my settings the picture in adrenalin under performance-tuning to get the best performance out of box. Set the max to 2530 and the minimum to 2430 first, then go up in increments of 20(max 2550), then set the minimum to 100mhz below that(minimum 2450). Setting the target wider than 100mhz can make your fps fluctuate quite a bit(I'm talking 155fps dropping to 80, you can definitely feel it and it doesn't feel good), and less than 100mhz can introduce instability. Next, play your most graphic intensive game(or stress test with furmark or kumbustor) for about 10-15 minutes. Keep adjusting this until it crashes(The screen will go black. Don't panic, it's just resetting your tuning settings to default. You didn't break anything. They're stressed way harder than most know how to during production.) then dial it back to the last stable minimum and max. Some cards can reach 2750, and some can only hit 2600 or less. It's all silicon lottery. The fan curve is up to you; mine is designed to be silent when it can be without compromising performance.

Okay, now onto the review. Imagine a world where you could get a GPU that plays most games at 1080p 60fps+ with only a 500w psu required. Now also imagine paying less than $350 for it. Welcome the RX 6600. Scorned by reviewers upon release, it was quickly branded a "boring" card because it wasn't built to be a 3060ti(basically a slightly underclocked 3070) competitor and complete 1080ti(although it does beat it in some games) killer. It was built to be a 3060 competitor according to amd, but I could care less about that. How does it game? Well, every title I've tested at 1080p ultra has ran at 60fps or higher outside of a select few. 1440p 60fps is feasible as long as you're willing to compromise a bit on settings. The power draw is fantastic too, with an average of 120w.

At the current price point of $300, there's nothing that can match the 6600.

Reviews.title: Nice card- AMD still struggles with drivers after all these years~
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2022
Reviews.text:
Video cards are finally dropping in price but given the current economics and world issues, I decided to grab one of these after watching many review videos on YouTube. This card performs very well (on par with the 3060), at a much lower price. Unfortunately, AMD drivers are still a convoluted mess IMO compared to Nvidia Drivers. With their Adrenaline package having a ton of settings, if you're not familiar with it, you will spend literally hours playing with all the different settings. There are some cool features in it, but I wish AMD would focus more on overall PC performance and stability and less on trying to be the gaming king. You can ditch Adrenaline all together by using device manager to install STD drivers, but you lose "ALL FEATURES"....all or nothing? Not a good compromise.

RSR- Radeon Super Resolution (Built into Adrenaline). It works well enough with upscaling and no real complaints (Works with most games) and is what I use for OW when I play.
FSR 1- I do not play any games that utilize this.
FSR 2- I believe only 1 game (Death loop) takes advantage of this.

I run my security cameras, (Amcrest) through my rig for live viewing and have noted a degradation in overall performance compared to the old 1060 SSC 6G that was replaced with this card. Given this card is newer, better performing (physically)...I have to blame this on the drivers from AMD.

Overall- good value, but I will most probably go back to Nvidia "if" the prices get better aligned with my budget. The VC is only part of the equation for a good performing card, but most critical are the Drivers. Because without solid drivers updated frequently, the best video cards are mediocracy at best.

Reviews.title: 3090 Ti cards are currently incompatible with a number of HMDs
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2022
Reviews.text: Just a word of warning: I had to return mine as it did not detect my HMD. It turns out this is a common issue with 3090 Ti cards and that while Nvidia is aware of the situation (it is now listed in their 'current issues') it remains unfixed for now. Obviously this was a prime target-market for Nvidia's tip-tier GPU, so how they managed to release a flagship card with this incompatibility is baffling, but there you have it. So if you are planning to buy one of these for use with VR you'll want to wait until Nvidia has fixed the issue. I returned mine as there is no way I could sit on a $2000+ video card this is functionally broken at this time and just hope that someday Nvidia will fix it.

Reviews.title: Scam alert Not a 3090 ti
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2022
Reviews.text: Check serial numbers on both your card and box, I used affirm to get what I thought was a 3090 ti, box says it's a 3090 ti, but all programs, benchmark tools etc all show it's a 3080, not ok, just no, I'm calling Amazon customer service tomorrow and demanding they make this right, clearly it's between them and MSI, this was shipped and sold by Amazon so I didn't think much of it, I did however wander why my game tests were not on par with 3090 ti performance, I checked drivers, even Nvidias auto detect says it's a 3080, this is just not ok, this was supposed to be a birthday present to myself, I've always wanted a top shelf card since I got into computers several years ago, I'm just not ok with this

Reviews.title: Crash to desktop problems with RTX cards
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2022
Reviews.text: It has been about a month & a half with this card. Constant crash to desktop while playing games. I have tried many many so called fixes to no avail. There are blogs & internet videos all about the crashes & voltage problems with no fixes yet still to date from manufacturers. I supposedly have a motherboard that should not be affected by this issue but it still is affected. 20+ games now tested & they all crash to desktop eventually. Some right away & some after 45 minutes to an hour of play. My old gaming computer NEVER had even close to this many crashes to desktop. I have updated, flashed turned on turned off switched out re-installed from BIOS to drivers to OS. "CRASH CRASH CRASH"!!! 7/16/2022, stay away from these cards. I have installed my old RTX 2070 Super & not one crash for the whole week of playing. I am extremely disappointed in this "RTX 3090ti" card!

Reviews.title: Performance BABY!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
As a famous pirate had once said....Hello Beastie...

And certainly a beast it is, this card blew my 1660 super out of the water no doubt about that, it has chewed up every single game I had thrown at it, full graphics 1080p or 1440 no problems.....now I haven't really done enough testing since I only had it for like a day, however I can certainly see a difference....and I might even be bottlenecking it too since my hardware is already on the older side, or weaker...

Ryzen 5 3600
DDR 4 16gb 3000mhz
Msi gaming plus b450 mobo

Yeah I'm pretty sure there is some bottlenecking but so far I haven't really noticed, price was good although not quite exact, rtx 3070 at MSRP usually fetch for 499 or 550 but I got mine at $599, not totally unreasonable but I couldn't pass up the deal it was the best I was gonna get, try looking for an rtx 3070 for lower than $650 (if you're lucky) I dare you....most of the 3070s you'll see here are around 700 and above and possibly weaker (friggin scalpers)....

If you are worried about LHR, just don't, that's really only meant to reduce performance for crypto-asshats, if you are going to use it for gaming you have absolutely nothing to worry about because the performance will be there....

Overall, I think there might be a shining light for us gamers as we move further ahead, my advice stay patient and be on the lookout, NEVER buy from scalpers....and if you're lucky and find a good deal, don't pass it up just grit your teeth and buy it......

Reviews.title: Hold the line?
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2022
Reviews.text:
I bought this after prices fell but are still wacky. I waited long enough to replace my RX 580. Perhaps if I held out longer, I could have paid less but I certainly got a better deal than many did and only paid $20 more over the price of the EVGA 3060 here on Amazon. Lol wacky pricing indeed.

Anyways I am very happy as this is a big noticeable upgrade for me. I also wanted to get one last EVGA card as they will no longer make cards. This card feels overbuilt for a 3070 and runs cool. My RX 580 fans would come on all the time, but I have not yet noticed them on this. I am not a big gamer and I expect this card will be good for many years. This completes my computer build that started over a year ago to replace my 10 year old setup. Obviously, the difference is huge.

Reviews.title: Optimal 2k Gaming GPU
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2022
Reviews.text:
This was my upgrade from an RTX 2060, and let me tell you... It was worth the upgrade! Before, I was able to game in 2k with good frame rates for most games, but not all. With this RTX 3070, I'm able to play every game in 2k and take advantage of my 144Hz monitors!

I bought this when it was on sale for $630, so it was definitely worth that price. This card packs a big enough punch that it would be solid even between $700-$800 as well.

The fan speeds and such are configurable through EVGA software, which is handy. Fresh out of the box, it wasn't too loud though. The 3 fan setup does a great job of keeping it cool as well. No complaints here!

NOTE: If you're running a micro ATX case, this card will probably not fit. I've got my PC in the Fractal Meshify case and I've got about a 1.5 inch clearance between the GPU and my front case fans. So be considerate of that when purchasing.

Reviews.title: I'm Done Waiting! Great Card!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
At 37 Years old, I FINALLY decide to build a gaming PC, and what happens!? "THE GREAT GPU SHORTAGE"! I Literally started buying parts over a year ago and I refused to pay scalper prices for a GPU. They finally hit a price I'm willing to pay, and I'm honestly glad I waited.
I ended up getting a 5800x3d, which wasn't even out when I started this build and that thing is an absolute gem. I tend to play high FPS games at lower resolution, and I also play minecraft...shhh. both of these situations tend to be more CPU bound from what I know... which isn't that much actually.
This gpu does everything I need and then some! I have a 1440 165hz moniter and I'm playing WarZone/BO multiplayer on MAX settings, Ray tracing on, getting 120++fps on 1440 and completely pegged at 144 on my 1080 144hz monitor.
Red Dead Redemption 2 looks like a whole new game (I'm coming from a gtx 1060 laptop).
Cyberpunk runs solid 120fps at 1440 Almost Max settings.
And I finally get to experience high end Minecraft Java Shaders, and my goodness is it glorious.
32gb 4000mhz ddr4 ram
5800x3d
850watt PS
MSI B550 Tomahawk

Reviews.title: Silent for the games I play.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2022
Reviews.text: I was loathe to drop the insane amount of $ for a new card, but my AMD RX580, I thought, was quickly becoming a dinosaur. I thought this card would be a vast improvement, and it is for the most part. None of the games I've played since purchase have caused the fans to spin up and the card doesn't break a sweat. However, it is a PCI-e 4.0 card being used in a 3.0 slot, so it's bottlenecked for now. I had benched the old RX580 in various benchmarking suites, then the RTX3080, and was surprised that the numbers were as close as they were. I'm betting the PCI-e 3.0 is why. Still, even limited at 3.0, a good card so far.

Reviews.title: Price/performance is same(or even better!) as budget cards, but it's insanely more powerful
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
Pretty good stuff!

Tested stock performance on 3Dmark - bottom 48% - slightly below average across 3080 owners.

Overclocked/optimized with curve at +75 at or above 1V and +165 at or below 850mV and the rest of the points set where they are stable in benchmarks -

+105 at 950mV
+135 at 900mV, etc

I arrived at these numbers after I did a bunch of benchmarking, stress testing locking card at each voltage point and testing that separately.
And later after solid performance everywhere, but crash in VR adjusted entire curve "-15" for extra stability

Now my performance is top 10% among other 3080.

However after all that I limited power to 85% to save power and reduce heat, increase card longevity. Performance penalty is pretty small - just couple of percent less. Besides I pretty much can play any game locked at my desired 141 fps with g-sync on 1440p screen. Card is a beast and if I was just gaming on a screen I'm not sure I'd get something so massively overpowered.

Most games were running just fine at 80+ fps 1440p on my old 2060 and for big chunk of games even 2060 was barely utilized.

But for VR and game-dev this 3080 is a game changer! HL:Alyx runs flawlessly now - no hitches, high quality butter smooth 120 fps on quest2.

And Unreal engine 5 demos actually work on this hardware! Editor runs fine with massive scenes in ue5 - no more memory issues thanks to 10Gb

data.label: EVGA GeForce RTX 3070 Ti FTW3 Ultra Gaming, 08G-P5-3797-KL, 8GB GDDR6X, iCX3 Technology, ARGB LED, Metal Backplate
data.description: EVGA GeForce RTX 3070 Ti FTW3 ULTRA GAMING, 08G-P5-3797-KL, 8GB GDDR6X, iCX3 Technology, ARGB LED, Metal Backplate.

Reviews.title: Great card when competitively priced between a 3070 and 3080
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2022
Reviews.text:
User Experience and Price
My reason for getting this card was to play on a 4k 60hz tv, and to have newer features such as DLSS and ray tracing. (I had a 1070 ti prior and it could never fully handle 4k without scaling down to about 60-75% resolution on bigger titles from 2016+, especially without DLSS support.) The 3070 ti handles just about every title I've tried from 2020 and before at 4k with no need for DLSS or scaling, high to ultra. I would personally recommend it for 4k, but if it is priced closer to a 3080 than a 3070 i'd wait and get a 3080 for 4k. I wouldn't call playing dying light 2 with RTX on at 4k a very smooth experience with this card, but I also don't have a 3080 to compare that to. Revisiting some games at 4k on a tv brings back everything I forgot I missed from consoles, and most games have been buttery smooth. Dying light 2, and tiny tina's wonderlands have needed some tweaking down from ultra.

Form Factor
It's Biiiig. I haven't had any case clearance issues with mid tower cases, but double check before you purchase. I had this in a build with a full ATX motherboard, and I was able to reach my cables around no problem (more on this later). The weight of this card introduces a little sag even while screwed into the case. While it is not drastic, in the future I would like to see an elegant solution included with heavy gpu's, be that an included riser, bracket, mount, or stand. If it's not secured and sagging at all I would recommend taking out the GPU before traveling or moving the computer. or at the very least lying the computer down to where the gpu is not being pulled down.

More on Size

(This is mainly if you use a micro ATX motherboard) In the past week I rebuilt into a higher airflow case and had a motherboard issue (Not Due To This Card. For transparency and maybe helping someone to avoid the issue i caused, it was my own user error mixing an ARGB up with an RGB header while connecting case RGB, therefore frying my board.) This lead to me getting a Micro ATX motherboard. The issues with a Micro ATX board pairing with this card might be mitigated with some more planning time, a different model of board, cable extensions, or in my case compromises. I couldn't use 2 out of the 4 sata ports on the board due to the card covering half of them, but these sata ports were mounted to the board vertically (popping up from the board rather than sticking out to the right) If you plan on moving your computer around often after building i'd either recommend getting a full ATX motherboard, or making sure that if it's micro ATX that the sata ports are sticking out to the side as to not stress your sata ports or squishing the cables. Front audio and usb's were also impossible to get to on the smaller motherboard as the card covered those completely. I will not take a star off for this because I knew the risks of getting a cheaper smaller board, and I don't need those ports as i'm running all audio through the hdmi and back usb.

Price

If you are torn between a 3070 a 3070ti and a 3080 (as i was) it might help to know that the 3070 ti is about 8% to 12% faster than the 3070, and the 3080 is about 15% to 20% faster than the 3070 ti. As prices varied at the time of this purchase those were the numbers I took into account. At my time of purchase (april 2022) a 3070 was 100$ cheaper, and a 3080 was $400 more expensive.

Power

I would recommend 750 watts for your PSU if you have a more power hungry CPU, I tested this card on a 650 watt power supply with a 3900x and did a power scan with precisionX and it recommended I go up to 750 watts. It didn't crash or make noise on the lower wattage psu, but i do feel I was right at the limit, and I felt like I was before checking as well. Better safe than cardless.

Conclusion

This is a great card. It's nice to look at with it's massive RGB bar of light. It runs cool and quiet. EVGA has a stellar track record with it's customer service, and has a long warranty. For most people buying this should be as simple as making sure the PSU can handle it, plugging it in, and getting drivers installed.

Reviews.title: Great for gaming, but ARGB doesn't sync with ASUS motherboards.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
Reviews.text:
I love the gameplay on my 1080p setup. Not planning to upgrade to 4k anytime soon. Runs pretty cool with stock fans. Usually, only one fan runs unless under load. I can use fancontrol software to adjust speed of the fans.

The only downside that I have with it is I use Armory Crate to control the ARGB on my ASUS motherboard, and it doesn't recognize the RGB bar on the video card. I have to use Precision to control the card's RGB bar. JackRGB and Signal RGB didn't sync for me either. The header on the card can control other RGB, but that header only goes out, so a incoming signal from the MB will not work, and my MB is control out also.

I did try to OC it slightly about 3%, and had no issues, but tuned it back down since all three fans spun up very dramatically.

Its's heavy, and sagged in my expansion slot, so I mounted it vertically in my case and bought an additional extension cable to connect it and an GPU brace support to help even with it off the mb.

data.description: "Get Amplified with the all-new ZOTAC GAMING GeForce RTX™ 30 Series based on the NVIDIA Ampere architecture. Built with enhanced RT Cores and Tensor Cores, new streaming multiprocessors, and superfast GDDR6X memory, the ZOTAC GAMING GeForce RTX 3080 Trinity OC LHR 12GB gives rise to amplified gaming with ultra graphics fidelity. Features: - 2nd Gen Ray Tracing Cores - 3rd Gen Tensor Cores - SPECTRA 2.0 RGB Lighting - IceStorm 2.0 Advanced Cooling - FREEZE Fan Stop - Active Fan Control - Metal Frontplate and Lighted Backplate - FireStorm Utility - VR Ready - LHR 52 MH/s ETH hash rate (est.)"Series based on the NVIDIA Ampere architecture. Built with enhanced RT Cores and Tensor Cores, new streaming multiprocessors, and superfast GDDR6X memory, the ZOTAC GAMING GeForce RTX 3080 Trinity OC LHR 12GB gives rise to amplified gaming with ultra graphics fidelity. FEATURES • SPECTRA 2.0 RGB Lighting • IceStorm 2.0 Advanced Cooling • Active Fan Control with FREEZE Fan Stop • Metal Frontplate and RGB LED Backplate • GDDR6X Graphics Memory • 2nd Gen Ray Tracing Cores • 3rd Gen Tensor Cores • VR Ready, NVIDIA DLSS 2.3 • NVIDIA GeForce Experience • NVIDIA G-SYNC, NVIDIA GPU Boos SPECIFICATIONS • NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080 GPU • 8960 CUDA cores • 12GB GDDR6X memory • 384-bit memory bus • Engine boost clock: 1725 MHz • Memory clock: 19.0 Gbps • PCI Express 4.0 16x POWER REQUIREMENTS • 750-watt power supply recommended • 350-watt max power consumption • 2 x 8-pin power connector CONNECTIONS • 3 x DisplayPort 1.4a (up to 7680x4320@60Hz) • 1 x HDMI 2.1 (up to 7680x4320@60Hz) • HDCP 2.3 support • Quad simultaneous display capable SOFTWARE COMPATIBILITY • Game Ready Drivers and NVIDIA Studio Drivers • Microsoft DirectX 12 Ultimate, Vulkan 1.2 • OpenGL 4.6 • Windows 11 / 10 (64-bit, April 2018 update or later) INSIDE THE BOX • ZOTAC GAMING GeForce RTX 3080 Trinity OC LHR 12GB • 2 x Dual 6-pin to 8-pin cable • User Manual DIMENSIONS • Length: 317.8mm (12.5in) • Height: 120.7mm (4.8in) • Width: 3 slot (63mm) (2.5in) BOX DIMENSIONS • Height: 440mm (17.3in) • Width: 282mm (11.1in) • Depth: 120mm (4.7in).

Reviews.title: Video Editing and Gaming Beast
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
This graphics card is fast. I am able to render footage out of Adobe Premiere faster than I've ever been able to. Sometimes I accidentally export projects twice because it finished before I realized it had started and I thought I forgot to start the render. I am easily able to run 4k, 120 FPS on high or medium graphics depending on the game. Right now I run Rainbow Six Siege on ultra at 2k for steady 200+ FPS.

It does all of this, without the fans getting louder than my house's A/C.

I hadn't ever used a Zotac GPU before, but I'm a fan now!

Reviews.title: Perfect upgrade!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2022
Reviews.text:
I upgraded from a 1050ti when this card hit $799 on Prime day. The graphics card arrives new, sealed, in box, shipped and sold by Amazon. The card was plugged in, wired with 2 8 pin dedicated connectors, and immediately booted up. Display resolution WILL be awful until you add drivers. Further, I recommend using AfterBurner and not Zotac excuse for an OC software, Firestorm. The LEDs are extremely bright out of the box, can be dimmed in Firestorm. I had to put a fairly aggressive fan curve on it to keep the card under 65C. Card plays PUBG 1440pUltra144, Fornite1440pUltra250+, BF2042 1440Ultra90~. Do not worry if the fans don't spin when you turn your pc on. Mine shipped with a 50C minimum temp to spin the fans. The card isn't terribly heavy, no real need for a support.

EDIT: I worry that this card actually fried a PCIE slot on my Z370 Pro4 motherboard. I don't think that board was well suited for a card of this caliber. Z690, in my now current build, works flawlessly.

The system sits as a 12700k, 3080 12GB, 32GB of 3200mhz Corsair LPX, Aiza A300 (Lian Li O11 knockoff), EVGA G5 1000W, and MSI 360mm AIO.

Reviews.title: Fell flat for me
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2022
Reviews.text: I really want to like this card after shelling out the money to upgrade from my 1070 To, unfortunately my experience thus far has been lacking. I am experiencing stuttering when trying to play a game on one monitor, while watching a video in the other, something that my 1070 was able to do without the video stuttering, on the same settings. The card is very loud and runs very hot, making me need to reconsider my pcie slot usage so I can try to free up more space in front of the fans. And since installing the card I have experienced crashes of games and windows blue screens noticably more frequently than before installation. I even performed a clean install of the drivers to ensure there were no conflicts. I will keep the card since my 1070 didn't have many days left in it, but will definitely be thinking twice before buying for my next upgrade

Reviews.title: Pleasantly Surprised with this Zotac RTX 3080
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2022
Reviews.text:
As always, Amazon.com delivers quickly and accurately. The delivery staff have always been top notch; I came home from work and the package is safely delivered: one hundred percent of the times without fails... Kicks UPS and FedEx in the rears!

As for this Zotac card, at first, I thought that this was simply a Zotac RTX 3080 Trinity 10Gb. Nope! It is a 12Gb version that works on first installation after a quick driver installation and registration. I got the 4K 120Hz to post with my LG monitor with ease. My Elden Ring and Cyberpunk games are now a joy to run compared to my old Aorus GTX 1080 Ti. The very best part is that it is super compact and fits perfectly in my Lian Li case. RGB customization is easy to setup and is gorgeous; it is a perfect fit for my build! The card does not even sag when mounted to my Asus motherboard. The fans are quiet and turn off during this review and regular non-gaming use clocking consistently at 34-35'C. I have zero thermal concern during game play. I ask myself, "How?" How did they engineer this beast? For me, it is worth every penny and is a perfect successor to my GTX 1080 Ti Xtreme cards. I highly highly recommend this product (coming from an owner of Asus cards and 4 Gigabyte Aorus GTX 1080 Ti Xtreme cards, this is a huge compliment). And it looks better than the more expensive EVGA version. Bravo to Zotac!

However, do your research of other cards from other third party vendors. They are all excellent cards. Do keep in mind that some cards are far superior compared to others, and their engineering limitations are not quite pronounced until enthusiasts push these cards to their limits.

data.label: ASUS GeForce RTX 2060 Overclocked 6G GDDR6 Dual-Fan EVO Edition VR Ready HDMI DisplayPort DVI Graphics Card (DUAL-RTX2060-O6G-EVO)
data.description: Experience silent and powerful gaming with the next-gen ASUS DUAL RTX 2060 O6G EVO. Featuring NVIDIA’s new Turing GPU architecture, the card’s innovative graphics stay frosty with 0dB dust resistant fans for a 50% cooling increase, while overclocking and monitoring are made easy with ASUS’ GPU Tweak II software.

Reviews.title: The little GPU that could.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2022
Reviews.text:
I had a Radeon Nitro r9 390x 8g 6k, but something happened to it. I decided not to spend a wad of cash since I don't do any intense gaming any more. So I got this card because it was under $400, it was OK for some lite gaming and it had two HDMI ports, plus two other ports for a max of 4 monitors.

I could tell from the packing that someone had returned this card, but it was alright for me. I suspect that anything returned would be examined and tested. So far, no problems.

I tested the card out on some gaming and it worked fine for what I play. It was also easy to setup. I booted and it took Windows about 30 seconds to find the drivers, setup the card and to arrange my dual monitors. I didn't even need to download anything. I also like that it is an ASUS card since my MB is also ASUS.

It also doesn't take up as much room. This card is shorter and not as thick as other cards. I was able to adjust my cables and even had enough slack to rearrange my cables in the case because I had a lot more room.

It also has the bonus of not drawing as much power. It only needed one of the AUX power cords and it is super quiet compared the my older card. It only has two fans and I can barely hear them over the other fans in the case, which is a nice change from my 390x which was extremely noisy.

So if you are looking for an inexpensive video gaming card, then this would be your pick.

Reviews.title: Really big!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2022
Reviews.text: This video card delivers very good results, but be advised that it is really big. I have a very big desktop case, and I had trouble even getting it into the case. The problem is the height above the motherboard. I had to remove the metal mounting bracket from the end of the card to even get it plugged into the PCIe slot. I was then able to reattach the bracket from outside the case. Next, the 8-pin power receptacle is mounted on the top (side away from the mother board), so when I plugged in the power cable, I could no longer put the cover back on the case. Fortunately there is small adapter you can buy on Amazon that effective turns the receptacle 180 degrees. After installing that, I could close the case and this graphics card works fine.

Reviews.title: Son is Happy
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2022
Reviews.text: My son loves this new graphics card. He said it runs much cooler than his previous one. Not that this takes away from the product itself, but the packaging used for shipping was awful. It arrived in an unpadded bag, which resulted in tears in the actual graphics card box. I would expect a several hundred dollar fragile item to be shipped in a box.
