Reviews.title: Quite Beast
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2022
Reviews.text:
I’ve had it about a week now and it is working great for 4K gaming on my 120hz OLED TV. Used in an Small Form Factor build in a NR200 Max ITX case. Paired with a 5600X CPU on an ASUS X570-I MOBO. Low temps and super quite even on performance mode. Haven’t even tried the quite mode. Couldn’t get the system above 75 Celsius when stress testing.

Note that while mine runs quite that’s not a guarantee, as many higher end cards suffer from coil while. It’s really just luck of the draw. However after much googling this seemed to be one of the quieter / cooler running cards overall (based on the limited benchmarking I could fine).

Reviews.title: This thing is awesome
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
So part of me wishes I had just forked over the extra 500 for a 3090, but I can't say I'm in any way disappointed with the 3080.

First off the quality is amazing, it's very well built.
The performance for gaming is far from disappointing, and has been very good.
Buuut....I also work with 3D programs like Zbrush, Maya, Blender and Substance Painter, and this is where I wish I had gone with the 3090. The 3080 does a great job still, it performs very well, most things still render rather fast, but every so often I can tell there is room for improvement.

Mine is also paired with a 5950x and 32 gigs of DDR4 RAM at 3600

Be sure to use 2 PCIE cables from your power supply, and get probably a minimum of 850w 80+ gold power supply to give yourself plenty of overhead.

Reviews.title: HD5770s and 6770s never came with 4GB of VRAM! AVOID!!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
The vast majority of HD6770s did not come with a VGA port. The real ones also require a 6-pin power connector. Most cards that have an output layout like this are fake and, seeing reviews from people saying it won't run DX11, I'm inclined to believe this isn't even a 6770 as those did run DX11. The listed clock speed is about 200mhz lower than the original cards which, at best, points to these being faulty cards flashed with a different BIOS to operate at a lower clock speed. HD 5770s and 6770s (same card with 2 names) also NEVER came with 4GB of VRAM.

Again, this points to this being a card with a fake BIOS. I've tested another faked GPU claiming to be a GTX 960 4GB and the card even reported itself as such to the computer. In actuality it was a GT640 with 1GB of VRAM. When a game would try to utilize the reported 4GB of VRAM that didn't exist, it would cause the computer to crash.

Best case scenario here, you get a GPU that was originally released in 2009 (as the 5770, again, identical to the 6770...AMD just renamed the same card 2 years later) which has not received driver support since 2015, running at 76% of it's original speed (which may be how it gets away without a 6 pin power connector...but I doubt it) and have to spend some time dialing in settings to avoid games using more than 1GB of VRAM so the computer won't crash. In other words KEEP SHOPPING!

Reviews.title: No Support Bracket, They Must Be Crazy
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2022
Reviews.text:
So far the card has been phenomenal performance wise. I've been playing everything at 1440p ultra locked 144fps at around 68 to 72c. It's a monster. I have it paired with a R7 5800X (OC) and 32GB DDR4-3200. Next gen definitely won't be seeing me. I won't be needing anything for a few good years and I'm glad I'm not out there gambling on the future of the market anymore, especially with the way the world is looking currently. The build quality is amazing. Metal everywhere, no plastic, and it looks great. I DO have a couple gripes with the card though, and I'll point them out below:

1. No Support Bracket In-Box: This is a premium product. It's definitely priced as such ($770 before tax), and it's an extremely big card. It's long, it's thick, and it's pretty heavy due to all the metal. There's no way in hell this card WON'T sag. I'm talking PRISON sag. How the hell can you package the 6900XT variant with a bracket but not this one, when they use the exact same cooler (if I recall correctly). Even if they don't by some chance, you still made the damn thing so you KNOW it needs support badly. I had to create a makeshift support stand out of toilet paper roll cores and masking tape, and it looks pretty stupid but it works. After spending over $820 in total for a GPU, it's a kick in the balls to have to dip again to get a bracket. You guys are wrong for not including your own bracket.

2. Coil Whine: First time in my life I've had a card with coil whine, and I've had a few. Luckily it's not loud. When the side panel is on I can't hear it, and my desktop sits on top of my desk right next to me, but it's there. I hear it when I remove the side panel while it's on running demanding games. I hear it pretty clearly. It's annoying as hell lol. Now I see why people go crazy over it. Thankfully like I said mines can't penetrate the side panel so I'm right as rain.

3. Connector Placement: This is the first GPU I've ever seen where the PCIe cables go in upside down. I've never seen this before and it threw off my cable management completely. I had to twist my cables in a way they weren't meant to twist so that they could go in upside down and now it looks ugly and hits the glass panel while routing to the left. You can feel the tension in the cables. I absolutely hate it, but with performance like this you get over things pretty quickly lol.

It replaced my Sapphire 5700XT Nitro+, which was still an utter beast even with today's games, and the performance leap is nothing short of enormous. Now I have a great card as a backup and an excellent card slotted in. I wanted the Nitro+ version of the 6800XT but the prices are goofy as hell. This is my first PowerColor product and so far I must say, the quality feels like the stuff I'm used to with Sapphire. Not quite as high, but a very close second.

Reviews.title: Big, really big
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2021
Reviews.text:
This card is an amazing gpu for almost every gamer, with the large pool of vram and the gpu horse power to back it up, it will demolish any game you throw at it, at 1440p ultra wide (1440:3440) it will keep a the frame rate well above 144hz with high and ultra settings in games like war zone and black ops. Haven’t tried it a 4K yet but will update. Now the down side, the ray tracing is unfortunately lacking, especially in full path traced games like Minecraft RTX that averages of 20 FPS, it does okay for ray tracing for the new call of duty games but too much of an impact for competitive gaming, great for the campaign though. Additionally it lacks dlss or some kind of competitor to boost the frame rate at high resolutions like the nvida cards, however it’s not as important as only a small number of games support it.

Final gripe is it is huge it is a full 3 pcie slots high and almost didn’t fit in my case because it is extremely long length, it fit in my lian li tu-150 but I wouldn’t recommend putting it in one

TLDR: amazing card for high frame rate modern AAA gaming, however leaves something to be desired for ray tracing profomance, also no dlss competitor and the card is massive

Reviews.title: Severely overpriced, even at MSRP
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2021
Reviews.text:

If you can find it in stock at MSRP (if we can even agree what MSRP actually is), it's a really great looking card, and the performance is good. These days, it's difficult to have a conversation about whether or not a graphics card is a good value, when you can't find anything at MSRP in stock, and the graphics card you can find, are either scalped here on Amazon, or used cards on other retailer sites.

The aRGB plug on this card, isn't well placed, and you'll have to find a creative way to hide the cable. There is software available from Powercolor that'll let you control the RGB on here, without syncing it to your motherboard through.

So for my $1400, its proportionally worth its value with the price gouged msrp's till the prices normalize.

The only issues I have is that my gpu has a coil whine when performing at max capacity but its conpletely harmless, juat annoying and the red backlight can not be shut off, but can be changed to other colors.

Reviews.title: I'm not sure what people hate about this GPU.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2022
Reviews.text:
I bought the RX 6500XT at a time when most GPU's where priced at double their usual price, if not more. At the time, it was a good price and despite people trying to tell me that it's not an upgrade from what I was using, it actually is.

I game at 1080p. This GPU will do it. It's only down side is that it has 2gb less RAM than my previous card. However, it makes up for it and I don't really notice it. Most of the games I play run better. The few that don't at least matches what my previous GPU can do.

If GPU prices were what they were last year, then I would buy this card again. If you play the wait and see game, then you don't know how long you'll be waiting. I couldn't afford to wait. When this RX 6500XT came out, I jumped on it and I don't have any regrets.

On the other hand the deliver was fastest than expected and the graphic was properly packed and of course completely new. So far so good, It's almost perceptible the noise while playing and the fans stop while you're not doing something demanding. Long story short, great purchase for someone looking for a cheap but efficent graphic card, specially if you come from a lower specs card. Btw I'm using PCI 3.0

Reviews.title: Vastly improved performance. Still could have gotten a better card.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2022
Reviews.text:
This card vastly improved my performance over the integrated solution in an AMD A10 processor. It gave a good performance boost over the previous video card I replaced. I did not expect perfection, but this did exceed my expectations based on the technical reviews. I was pleased with the performance paired with my A10 processor, but since I have upgraded to an Ryzen 7 5600X, I suspect this is now a bottleneck of the system.
I would recommend this paired with a slightly less powerful processor as it gave a much needed performance boost, and allowed me to smoothly play games on lower settings. Since upgrading the processor, the entire system runs much better (though I did have some driver issues with Window's generic drivers after upgrading to Windows 11, but this was eventually solved with AMD's authentic drivers.) I am now able to play on higher graphics settings. I suspect an upgraded card with more memory would allow me to run about anything. It was worth the investment.

For the price at the time of purchase, about $190 in June 2022, it may be worth it to you if you just need something to get up and running while waiting for the next gen or for prices on used hardware to drop more. Reviews.title: Better than I expected. Whisper silent w/ OC
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2022
Reviews.text:
I must explain my ratings.

First, it is very quiet IF you have the right settings. It's tempting to say, blast the fans to get a higher overclock, but I promise you, the noise is not worth a marginal performance boost. Besides, you can still get about a 100-200MHz overclock without putting the fan past 50%, hell, you can do it at 40% or lower. In fact, out of the box, the fan is set to be very quiet while the voltage curve is maxed out. And yes, out of the box, the core temps will reach over 100 degrees (the junction temp). So word of advice, LOWER THE DAMN VOLTAGE. This will take some tweaking, and you must enable overclocking, but lower voltage will not only make it run at lower temps and higher clock speeds, but it will also significantly reduce coil whine, which you are very likely to hear at 1.15v.

Second, ngl, this is stupid expensive. If you can't justify spending $800 on a graphics card, don't do it. Just get the 6700 or 6750xt or whatever that is more affordable. The performance difference is like 5-15% difference depending on the game.

Last, this thing performs extremely well. I also bought a 4k 120hz oled tv to use as my main monitor and I didn't expect to be able to play 4k @ 120hz, but it's more than doable with this card depending on the game and settings of course. You will still get the hitching/stutters that lower performance cards get when you look around too fast on many games. Stuttering, like what happens in UE4 games is a result of clutter and high resolution textures and models. You won't see the same type of stuttering on older games (like the Witcher 3, Borderlands 2, etc.) so much because they just simply don't have as much clutter, or high resolution textures/models, so everything in the scene will easily load into VRAM or cache (or whatever it is that is slow) before a frame renders at 120fps. Performance is not guaranteed. However, I still was pretty shocked the performance I saw with this card, it definitely performs better than I expected.

tl;dr
Lower the voltage, out of the box the curve is maxed out and the card gets HOT and coil whine will be noticeable. Only buy if the cost is not an issue, or you need it for a specific reason (like you are a game dev or researcher). And finally, it performs like a dream, but it's not perfect because nothing is.

Reviews.title: Awesome 6800xt
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2022
Reviews.text:
Fantastic card, after owning it, I think XFX is a great brand and the cooling performance was great.

This card is built very well. It does make a bit of coil noise though. It's not too bad as long as you're wearing headphones you won't hear it at all. If you game with speakers at very low volume it might be a bit of an issue for you. It was not a dealbreaker for me, i use headphones and I could hear absolutely nothing even with no volume on in the headphones.

This card is incredibly well built though and everything I hear about XFX as a company is very positive, I hear they really stand behind their products. If I you are in the market for 6800xt I definitely reccomend this. I ultimately chose to go with an RTX 3080 though for the same price, because I think at the same price you get alot more for your money with the 3080 (raytracing and DLSS (which is definitely better than FSR 2.0).

Assuming you have a power supply that can power the 3080, because it consumes like 100 more watts than this 6800xt, this 6800xt only consumed like 255 watts according to all the monitoring software I used (afterburner, AMD Adrenalin, GPU-Z) which is fantastic, while my 3080 (ASUS TUF Gaming 3080 12gb) sucks down between 355 - 370 watts which is a lot, so I needed to upgrade my power supply, I had a 650 seasonic focus gold and it was running the 3080, but I don't want to push my PSU to the limit like that so I got a 1000 watt EVGA supernova to power that. Now with this XFX 6800xt at 255 watts on the otherhand, the 650 will power it no problem at all. The card can be cranked up to like 270 watts for overclocking.

Overall after owning this card for a while I think it's a great card, and that XFX is great brand, I trust them to make solid quality products.

Reviews.title: Beware…. It’s Big!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2022
Reviews.text:
This is the longest card I’ve ever seen… it’s a bit less than 14”. Thankfully I’m still using the Corsair Obsidian 900d case. The only problem with the 900d and it’s obsolete design is it’s difficult to screw down these 4.5” wide cards. A magnetic flex bit holder is highly recommend for this task. Due to the design of this card, it was almost impossible to screw the card down, whereas I didn’t have a whole lot of trouble screwing down an EVGA FTW3 card.

The 6800xt was the card I wanted all along, but I ended up getting a 3070 because that’s what I was able to find in early 2021. I wasn’t willing to pay the post tariff prices for the 6800xt. Then I used the Step-up program to get a 3080.

At lower a res like 1080p, the 6800xt crushes it. It does well at 4k which is what I use. R/T still has a long way to go so I don’t use that and the 6800xt is too powerful for needing DLSS or FSR. The 6800xt is a much, much better buy than a comparable priced 3070ti.

The only strange observation I have to report is my Ryzen system boots quicker with this card. I don’t know why… no idea. The POST time is what has been reduced. Now it takes 10 to 12 seconds to get into the O.S.

Since 2019, I’ve had a RX 580, RX 5700xt, Radeon VII, 1070ti, 1080ti, 3070, and a 3080 in my Ryzen system with a Crosshair VIII Hero board. It would take about 30 seconds to get into the O.S. with these cards. The Pascal cards took the longest.

Fan speeds will stay at around 25% to 40% if you don’t set a fan curve. Hot spot temps could be better at stock settings. The card is loud once the fan speeds go above 65%, but it’s not annoying like other cards. GPU wattage is a bit over 250w. It would pay dividends to undervolt this card, but pretty much every CPU & GPU should be undervolted. With every GPU, I recommend undervolting and setting a fan curve that will keep hotspot temps at or below 80c.

Reviews.title: Exceptionally Quiet!!! 👍👍👍
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2022
Reviews.text:
I've owned many graphics cards since 2011. And, while gaming under heavy loads, this card is fast and has the quietest stock triple fan cooler I've ever owned!! This Radeon RX 6800XT Core edition is Absolutely Amazing! When using the Radeon software it overclocks like a Beast as long as you're using a good quality power supply. It scales very well and is very stable with manual overclocks! Also, I was able to get a extra performance boost after I enabled "smart access memory" in the bios!

Now, for the only "CON" I have regarding this card. I usually water cool ALL of my graphics cards purely for performance, aesthetics and the superior silence over air cooling. So, I was very disappointed that no one makes custom water blocks for the 6800XT Core edition cards! But, there are custom water blocks for the reference 6800 and the 6800XT Black edition cards. I've searched everywhere and learned that EKWB, Alphacool and BykSki do not make water blocks for the core edition cards due to the different PCB layout from the black edition cards.

So, after I reached out to EK, Alphacool, BykSki and several other waterblock manufacturers to confirm this. I reluctantly upgraded from the 6800XT to the XFX Speedster Zero 6900XT RGB EKWB Limited Edition. I didn't want to upgrade. But, the Zero came with a custom waterblock and it's one of the fastest 6900XT's with only Sapphire's Toxic being the fastest.

Reviews.title: Awesome Card - Literal Game Changer
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2022
Reviews.text:
So I just paid 1700 bucks for a Card with a 900 dollar MSRP to replace a Card that had a 600-dollar MSRP. AM I insane? Yes, but I have no regrets. A year ago, I didn't get in the EVGA queue, because I was happy with my RTX 2070 Super (definitely regret that). I was gaming on twin 34-inch Superwides at 21:9 UHD 2560 x 1440. Frame rates were good. Then I got a Quest 2 with Virtual Desktop and a dedicated wifii router. I upgraded to faster Memory with 64GB capacity and had the Quest 2 do some of the legwork with the spacewarp feature in Virtual Desktop. Performance was smooth, but quality was just acceptable at medium in VR.

Then I got a Samsung 49-inch Super Ultrawide running 32:9 at 5120 x 1440 this past black Friday and it became clear The RTX 2070 Super just wasn't going to cut it anymore if I wanted full screen 32:9 gaming at those resolutions.

Let me be clear upgrading to the RTX 30380 was a nightmare. First of all, it runs hot as hell (I think especially this XC3 model). Secondly, it draws 100 more watts than the 2070 Super. Fortunately, I researched requirements while I waited for this card to arrive, and I purchased a new power Supply in advance. I upgraded from a 650-watt Power supply to a Corsair 750 watt modular gold power supply.

I popped in the card started gaming and it was stuttering immediately I began to panic, but I took a deep breath and checked temps. I realized immediately the card ran wayyyy too hot for my current chassis configuration. CPU was hitting 100 C and Ambient Temps in the Chassis was cooking with the 3080 in it. So I purchased a Corsair RGB H100i ICUE AIO 240mm cooler to replace my 120mm and I reconfigured the airflow and added fans. Now, I can play games in VR on Ultra and let me tell you the difference is INSANE. It cost me an arm and a leg but now I can get the best out of my screen and my VR games and for me that was worth it.

The only downside is now my PC is basically a space heater because the new cooling system dumps heat out of my PC at such a high rate. My advice is If you are a medium quality PCVR or Pancake UHD player stay with a 2070 Super and wait for the RTX 4k series possibly launching this summer. But for 4k/5k Gaming or VR, if you can't wait, get the extra flops of 3080 or 3080ti because they make all the difference.

Sidenote: Yes, it is nuts to pay what I paid but it also means I can sell my 2070 Super on Ebay for a nice chunk of change because of the current market so you need to consider that. Current bid on my old Card is currently at around 600 bucks which is the MSRP I paid for it 2 years ago, so you can offset the cost a bit.

Reviews.title: Finally!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2022
Reviews.text:
Yes. Oh yes.

Packaging:
Box and card came in surprisingly pristine condition. I was worried about this the most, but there was solid protection, and protective covers on all the connectors (and a protective plastic wrap over the heat plate you'll want to remove).

First Steps:
The VERY FIRST thing you should do when you receive this card is check that the ID on the board matches the one on the box, and then IMMEDIATELY create an account with EVGA and register the card in your name so you have an active warranty. This card is a nontrivial investment, and registration is quick & painless.

Price:
I have been waiting almost two years for this moment. This is as close to MSRP as we've ever seen this puppy get. I jumped on the opportunity, as it's also quite literally the only 3080 that will even remotely fit in my micro ATX case. It gets a little hot, but far below maximum. I can now run most games at max settings. In fact, the only ones that still have sub-60fps at a 4K resolution are Star Citizen and Microsoft Flight Simulator, but pop those down to 1080p and you're above 60fps, whereas without the new gpu, they would fluctuate from 15fps to 30fps.

Power Requirements:
Keep in mind, we've reached a plateau of power usage and the nextgen 4000-series looks pretty bleak from here. I upgraded my 650w psu to an 850w to prevent throttling at high usage, and am flat out unwilling to put up with 1.5kw for a 4080, much less wait to find out whether any manufacturer will even be able to make one that fits. No thanks. This 3080 will do perfectly until we see those power requirements optimized.

So far, so good. I love this card. Don't forget to enable resizeable bar in your bios, enable hardware-accelerated gpu scheduling in your OS, set your OS & nvidia power profiles to performance mode, and set your nvidia shader cache to 10GB!

Reviews.title: Not worth it
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2022
Reviews.text:
I decided to finally try a 3080 after using a 1080ti for the past several years. I am used to the hybrid so of course that is very quiet. This card is really quiet too because they want to just generally leave the fans off and let it get to 80c before worrying about it. I am not comfortable with that heat level. So while running Hunt Showdown I kick all three fans to 100% and about 3300RPM I think. That makes the temp way more tamed down to a reasonable level. It is loud, but I play with headset and loud games so not the worst part. The worst part is that all research I did showed that this thing is 100% faster that the 1080ti across the board and in some cats much more. But the proof is in the pudding and while it was fun checking out Quake II RTX my gains in Hunt Showdown were not even apparent at all at times. Like it can not even do 120FPS@ 1080p. The 1080ti holds it's own against the 3080 just fine. maybe like 10 less FPS. I will be going back to it for now. For such an expensive card two generations later I am very, very disappointed to say the least. Outrageous

It was easy enough to start the return, being sold by Amazon.com itself, but some info was wrong and now getting someone on the phone to handle it is a serious chore. I guess with standards going down everywhere the level of phone support you get here is on the chopping block. Just get someone on the phone that can help already.

Reviews.title: Great GPU
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2022
Reviews.text: This GPU is great. I only marked it down because it's a little loud (when running games) and it does run sort of hot. Mine was around 78-83C when running games like Red Dead Redemption 2 and GTA 5. Obviously your GPU is going to run hot but as I mentioned before, it's not as quiet as I would like it to ideally be. Make sure you have a PC with good airflow if you are going to get yourself one of these because it needs it. EVGA has great support as a company and if you register your device on their website you get a 3-year warranty so make sure to do that. Very happy I upgraded.

Reviews.title: Wonderful GPU
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2022
Reviews.text:
I didn't wanna comment super-early after buying a GPU that ain't exactly cheap to me. I am the current owner now of team (Multiple) GREEN, and team RED GPU's.

This is after having it for 2-3 months I believe. Didn't look at the purchase date o well..

I did have a few crashes when i first got this GPU. It was software related, the GPU wasn't even out on the market for 1 month at the time. After 2 updates, those crashes do not exist at this point. It wasn't often also, or when under stress like playing STAR CITIZEN, COD, ELITE DANGEROUS, and etc. I had 2 crashes total prior to the updating.

The previous card, I used to replace the other was a 2080 S. Which is and still is a great GPU. But this thing on performance and benchmarking smokes the 2080s. Also smokes the 3070, its more close to the 3080 in my eyes of performance after comparing just not my own tests. But tests online who do this kind of thing for a living. Not talking about LINUS tech tips either. More of a GAMER NEXUS kind of view on the GPU. Getting this is way cheaper than buying a Nividia by FAR FAR. Not sure how it works on streaming. I don't stream anymore. But thats the only thing they got over team red is that nividia decoder on video is way better. Not saying this card can't do it. I am sure it can do that, and then some. Long as you got a good enough CPU so you can actually get the true power out of this thing. As in for the bottlenecking for most that suffer cause they got themselves a super beefy GPU but are still running an ancient cpu/mobo combo. Also id say get nothing less than 800w PSU cause this thing sucks up the power around 230ish Watts ive seen.

The cost is what I liked. Not paying 1k+ for a team greener that some scalper was selling up to almost 2k at one point. Therefore i am beyond happy with the purchase. Will I ever buy another Nividia GPU? Of course!! Been buying there items before they were NIVIDIA. "3DFX" Just the performance, power, and price you can't beat. There is even the 6850 XT also its a step up from this one. Just make sure you do your research as I did prior. Don't follow others on youtube, that might seem to know but literally are just copy/pasting what main channels do. Ow ya!! Jay two cent's knows his stuff also! Not hating on Linus just I think the other guys do much better presenting there finds and research!

This also is the MERC319, its the more ramped up version.

Reviews.title: Read the reviews!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2022
Reviews.text:
I was hesitant on buying this gpu because 1.) it's a brand I don't know 2.) there is only one photo and it's not the right box 3.) it has only some reviews. But it was at a competitive price with the other gpu's I was looking at so I took the risk and bought it.

It turns out my risk paid off. The product you get is the Merc version and it is the 6750XT. The packaging was solid and the gpu has the right dimensions. It does not come with a gpu brace, so I would recommend getting one off of Amazon so that you help prevent gpu sag. The performance it what I expected for the card based off benchmarks and videos I have seen, and the noise level is good (no coil whine or loud fans). The logo on the side lights up, and you can download their software to change the colors (no thanks). The games I play (Valorant, Overwatch, GTA V, Witcher 3) run great at 1440p 144hz (with some tweaks for the more demanding titles). So overall I am happy with my purchase.

Reviews.title: Flawless 1440p

Now I don't have as high of Time Spy scores as others on here. But I got nearly 1400 with the auto overclock setting on and the card was cool the entire time. This score places the 6750XT above the 3070ti and within shooting distance of the 6800. Fantastic card.

Reviews.title: WOW.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2022
Reviews.text:
Absolutely beautiful, sleek design. Not getting RGB with this one but the text and XFX logo light up in a static white/red color. Very long, probably the longest 6750XT out of the whole lot. BUT, if you've got the room, this thing is a BEAST for gaming at high refresh rates 1080p(165hz-240hz)/1440p(144hz).

Alongside the gaming capabilities this GPU has phenomenal cooling at basically inaudible noise levels. Considering its TDP is 250W, the fans and build quality need to be really solid, and this graphics card delivers on all fronts.

Apex Legends MAX settings 1080p/165hz: Avg. FPS - 275
Forza Horizon 5 EXTREME settings 1080p/165hz: Avg. FPS 125

Probably best for the price out of the 6750XT line right now at $469.

Reviews.title: Solid, Quiet & Effective
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2022
Reviews.text:
Despite the fact that the 6750XT is a minor refresh of the 6700XT, this is a solid offering from XFX. Excellent performance, low noise, and it looks impressive!

My previous card was a PowerColor Vega 64 Red Devil which was a similarly large, triple fan card, and when it was running at max load, it sounded like a jet engine, ate up tons of power, and kicked out a ton of heat. The Speedster, by comparison, is quiet and cool.

I was on the fence picking up an RDNA2 card this late into the cycle, since the next generation of cards should be launching later in 2022. I had wanted the XFX 6800XT since its launch and was unwilling to pay the absurd prices the past few years, but that gave me time to re-evaluate how much power I actually needed from a card. Since I still play at 1080p (with plans to get a 1440p monitor at some point soonish) and my cpu is also a few years old, for the price, I came to the conclusion that the 6750XT would be the sweet spot to hold me over for a few years. Absolutely no regrets. This is a great card that runs everything I throw at it and maintains a good frame rate at high/ultra settings.

My recommendations would be:
If you absolutely need a card now, the Speedster MERC319 6750XT is well worth it. Solid design if it fits your build.
If you're looking to upgrade from a Vega64 (or similar), its more of a judgement call, but again, I am quite happy with the upgrade.
If you have a more recent card, my honest recommendation at this point would be to wait for the next generation.

Minor Update 8/12/22:
Popped this card into a slightly newer build paired with a 5800x processor - max frame rate is marginally higher, but minimum is also improved, making for silky smooth gameplay at 1080p on high/ultra settings in most games. And this card, despite being a triple fan design, hardly makes any sound under load. After having a few months to play with it, I still absolutely love it!

Reviews.title: A new level of anxiety that I did not know I needed
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2022
Reviews.text:
I had no justifiable reason to make this purchase.

My current PC is an X570 based Ryzen 9 5950X machine that was equipped with an MSI branded RTX 2070 Super card. My display is a 1080p 144hz refresh rate Free Sync HP 25mx monitor. For the games I am playing the RTX 2070 Super has been more than adequate.

I saw this Gigabyte card as In Stock and at what appeared to be street price/MSRP and shipped and sold by Amazon and not a 3rd party seller. After checking specs of my current machine, that my case had more than enough clearance for the size of this monstrosity and per Gigabyte's website, my PSU, an Apevia branded 800-Watt Gold certified unit, should be able to carry the load, I impulsively bought this card.

Installation was easy enough and I have now been running the car for about a week.

Due to my gaming habits and what I am playing and the display I am playing on, I have not experienced any tangible benefit as of yet. I literally just finished playing Far Cry Primal. Yes, it's 2022 and I played Far Cry Primal on a 1080P 144hz display split between an RTX 2070 Super and a RTX 3080 TI. And I have seen no difference. I am sure the monitor low specs are the bottleneck and is why I did not experience any uplift. I am not saying it is not there, but I did not experience anything tangible.

I do understand that the card is more powerful than what I was running but my situation is not giving me a chance to see any uplift hence the folly of this purchase.

The card itself though consumes significant more power over the RTX 2070 Super. However, compared to other RTX 3080 TI's from Asus, EVGA and MSI, whose cards are recommending 850W, I am hopeful that Gigabyte's 750W recommendation really means 750W and that my non main stream name brand PSU even with its 50W over recommendation buffer will be efficient enough to carry this card. Especially, heading into summer months, I worry that PSU efficiency will drop as ambient room temperature rises. I hope my Central AC can adequately keep this card supplied with cold air and that my PC case has adequate cooling.

Even with playing the aforementioned Far Cry Primal, after about 10 minutes of play, this card definitely kicks into "high gear". It starts sucking down the power, and I hit temps of around 72-73C. I used the Gigabyte Aorus Engine software to write performance metrics to a log file while gaming and then input this "csv" data into a spreadsheet so I can then sort high to low on the various fields such as power usage in watts, fan speed rpm and temperature.

I should probably run MSI Afterburner's overlay in real time to watch this data since that would be more efficient.

I have read that 3080 series GPU based cards can "power spike" and again, I hope that I am within Gigabyte's specs and this does not happen to me. I have yet to play anything modern that engages RT cores and stresses the card. As it is now, the fan noise is significant when the card is under load. I have had PC's that have been more obnoxious sound wise but it is significant enough that you will notice the noise when it is doing its thing.

Again, going back to the Far Cry Primal game, when actively doing first person stuff, the card spun up and the noise and power draw are significant at this time, but if I would open the in game full screen map, you would hear the card spin down almost immediately as the workload changed. And then when going back to first person action, the card would ratchet back up.

So I am truly concerned that if the PC is hopping with CPU and GPU maxing out, that I may actually overload the machine or thermally damage something. Again, I should be within spec, but with the noise and the actual "feel to the touch" of the exhaust air that comes out the back of this card under load, it is truly something to give you pause. The exhaust is not just "warm" but borderline hot. Not as bad as a hair dryer but borderline "hot".

I perform no overclocking and run all the components within spec. This card has a factory overclock and I do run my RAM with the XMP 3600 profile, but that is it. No overclocking on my end as far as fiddling with CPU multipliers and bumping voltage or whatever sorcery is needed for Overclocking.

Some other non-gaming thoughts beyond heat, noise, power usage and the aforementioned paranoia.

I did try some transcoding in Handbrake using the H.264 Nvenc encoder. It seems to be decent. At least it does better than the 5950X's multiple threads. I do not really do a lot of video transcoding and I cannot say this is any better or worse than the old RTX 2070 Super but it seems capable if needed for transcoding.

For my day job, I am fortunate enough to sit at this same PC and drive a glorified RemotePC session, attend Zoom meetings, web browse, and have multiple Mobaterm SSH connections open. For normal non game workloads, the PC sounds like it did with the RTX 2070 Super. PC has the silent ambient sounds of fans doing there thing. No better or worse than before putting this card into service. So for long hours of productivity, I do not have the anxiety that happens when playing games.

Registering the card on the Gigabyte Aorus website to claim the 4th year of warranty was easy enough.

I realize this write up is scatterbrained and all over the place. It comes across as though I regret this purchase and I do not. While, paying the premium for a card of this class for my situation may not have been the best course of action, I am excited to use this card going forward. I do hope to get a better monitor, something in the 1440P high refresh range. I tend to hold onto my PCs for several years and since the AMD AM4 platform is at the end of the road, I do not see any significant upgrades beyond this in the machine's future. With the rumors of what RDNA3 and NVidia Ada Lovelace will potentially draw, I do not see that type of card in this machine's future since I would have to replace the PSU with a beefier one.

If you are in a situation where you have a display that can take advantage of this class GPU, and a PC with adequate power, cooling, and clearance, then by all means indulge yourself if you are not financially hurting yourself. Just make sure to temper your actual need over want. I did not take this advice myself but I realized that before making this purchase.

Reviews.title: Do this to get more performance, lower temperatures and use less power!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2021
Reviews.text:
I plan to updated this review as I get time to do some testing so bare with me.

So far the few things I tested the temps barley went up a few degrees. I plan to test a few more intense games such as Metro Exodus and CyberPunk 2077.

I've heard undervolting these cards can make them run cooler and quieter with little to no loss in performance. I plan to do some voltage testing and give updates here for others to benefit from.

GUIDE TO UNDERVOLTING:

The idea of undervolting is to get the same or more performance from your GPU with lower power usage and better temperatures. Generally GPUs are designed to have an optimal power usage to run it, that optimal level is usually much higher than needed and thus causes excess heat and increases your power bill. Most video cards can get more out of it for less power if not, at the very least the same. Additionally, your video card won’t dynamically clock as much giving you varying FPS spikes.

Few things to note before we begin:
1. Before you get your hopes up you should understand that not all GPUs are made equally and your millage may vary, but regardless you should get something out of this if you do this correctly.

2. This does not harm your video card if done correctly, if anything it will potentially make it last longer. This also does not void your warranty. That being said, I nor anyone else who instructs you how to do this will NOT be held responsible if you do something wrong and somehow blow up your video card. Feel free to do your own additional research.

3. Game crashing is normal during testing, as this is trial and error till you figure out what is a stable setting for your GPU.

STEP 1:
Download and install "MSI Afterburner". I will not be linking this, you can search this online and find the program. I will also assume you learned to set up the on screen monitoring. Do a search on that too so you can make sure everything is working correctly in STEP 4. You can do that in the Afterburner settings menu. I recommend having at least Framerate, GPU Power usage, GPU voltage, GPU temperature, GPU ram, Core Clock and Memory Clock usage on. You might even want to play a few games and see what your temperature and clock speeds hover at before so you have something to compare.

STEP2:
Open MSI Afterburner, click the gear icon seen in my second image circled blue. This will open the settings menu. In my image 3, make sure those settings match your settings menu.

STEP 3:
Once that is done go back to my image 2, and click the button circled in red or click “CTRL+F” on your MSI Afterburner. This will bring up a curve editor menu as seen in my image 4. Keep both MSI Afterburner and this curves menu open side by side and follow each sub step below:

1. In image 2, there is a section boxed in yellow. Pull the Core Clock slider down to -250 on your Afterburner and click the check mark at the bottom center located under your GPU name. You should see the curves editor updated with that change.

2. In my image 4, you can see my curve editor for reference. On the bottom of your curve editor, you will find the millivolt (mV) and on the left you will see the core clock speed. We already brought it down -250, so the next goal is to select a millivolt and pull it up to the appropriate core clock speed. In my case I set it at .875mV at 1905mhz core clock. I’ve seen some as low as .830mV at 1905 and beyond but it crashes for me lower than this so it will vary for you too. I suggest starting at around .830-.850mv at 1900mhz+. Once done, once again click that check mark button, but this time press the “floppy disk” icon to the left of the check mark button and click the “1” to the right side of your Afterburner to save your voltage curve. This way you can click the “1” to select this voltage profile. You can make many more if you choose to by testing what works for you.

STEP 4:
Now in this step, we want to make sure you have on screen monitoring on as stated in STEP 1. Run a game, preferably something current and high end. Cyberpunk 2077 is a good example, but something like Control Ultimate Edition or Horizon Zero Dawn will do. Play normally and see if everything is running smooth. If you experience no crashes after a few hours then your clock should be stable. If you’re feeling bold, you can try lowering power at the same core clock speed or increasing speed at same power usage.

However, if you crash return to STEP 3 and try a higher voltage with the same or lower core clock speed. This is trial and error so be patient. Try different games once one is stable too, just in case. Once you settled on your clock speed you should have better power to performance than stock but how much depends on your silicon lottery. You should be getting a few degrees cooler and using a bit less power.

BONUS TIP FOR THOSE RUNNING EXTRA HOT CARDS:
You can get even better temperatures if you replace your thermal pads inside your GPU. Do an online search if this tutorial was not enough to get your thermals low enough.

performance is id say at least double than a 1080, with raytracing on in cyberpunk 2077 its like 20-30 fps but with dlss its average of 80 fps so dlss definitely makes a huge difference. I play games at 1440p.

I also play arma 3 and modded stalker/fallout 4 etc games and they were already running really well so didn't notice a difference cuz once i'm already in 60fps range i kind of stop noticing? but this one runs quieter and cooler temps which does matter a lot to me cuz my cpu already runs pretty warm.

my system is older ddr3 system with a 4790k, 32gigs of ram and ssd. still runs games like a champ but i'm sure i have a cpu bottleneck but i don't feel like getting a new mobo yet.. but i assume whe i get a new ddr5 system this things gonna

Reviews.title: I can finally see enemies!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2022
Reviews.text:
I came from a 1060 that I had problems seeing enemies while playing online multiplayer, graphic intensive games: I had to run on lower settings to keep the game running, but that made seeing enemies difficult. With this card, I was able to run the games at high or ultra settings and make the matches more enjoyable as I am able to see better.
I gave it a 3 star for value because when I bought it in May 2022 the card was just slightly over MSRP.

Reviews.title: Great and solid card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2022
Reviews.text: Really solid gpu you will get your moneys worth but wait till the price goes down again, I got it for $799

Reviews.title: More FPS! More quality! Why not both?
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2022
Reviews.text:
I'm so happy I upgraded to this RTX 3080 TI

I'm a gamer, and I want to run the latest games at high quality settings on a 1440P monitor at 120Hz. I want high image quality, shadows, volumetric shading, and real time ray tracing.

No problem.

The only thing that I'm even mildly disappointed by is that this card doesn't include a USB C jack. my previous card (a 2080 Super) did, which meant I could use it with a USB C touchscreen monitor. But that's on me, since I chose this card, rather than one that does have the jack I want.

Aside from that little detail, I'm 100% happy with this card, and I'd buy it again.

Reviews.title: Works great, noisy as hell when overclocking.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2022
Reviews.text:
Frames: 4/5. On ultra or high settings for triple A games; +/-120 FPS in 1080p ~60 FPS in 4k. Graphic don't stutter or are hardly noticeable. Excellent ray tracing.

Price: Horrendous. Like every other graphic card on the market, way above MSRP. Even when it was "on sale", tax offset the discount by a large margin. It's basically a pricier 3090, with a minor 12% increase in performance.

Noise & Temperature: I'm kind of iffy on this one. Most games that I run (on ultra settings with a 60 FPS frame cap), it hardly made any noise, but once I run Cyberpunk 2077 or any other triple A game uncapped, the fans or heat sink make a high pitch noise so I would have to cap or lower my settings.
Under heavy load, the GPU temps ran very high; heating up the entire system averaging around 75~80 C. I regretfully went with an air CPU cooler and saw that temperatures stayed at a steady mid-high during most usage.

Overall; works great, very expensive, and runs worryingly hot and noisy.

Reviews.title: Pretty beefy honestly

Reviews.title: Great budget card
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2022
Reviews.text:
Old man Dad on a budget here. Purchased this to upgrade from onboard graphics when stadia was announced that they were cancelling.

Slapped it in, loaded up Elder Scrolls Online and can say I'm pleased with the card. I run it on the high setting no problem. It can handle ultra but the framerate drops below my comfort but it can run it.

For a budget card it works well for me. Would recommend.

(I'm running a 10th gen core i5 with only 16gb of ram...still the card performs better than expected)

Reviews.title: I NEEDED A CARD TO CRUISE AROUND THE INTERNET WITHOUT ISSUE AND THIS IS IT!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2022
Reviews.text:
I just needed a basic video card to cruise around the internet without being stifled by lame performance of a cheap video card. While this card is a tad expensive it is not priced at the ridiculously insane prices of the middle to high end gaming video cards in 2022. This GPU has done the job of letting me go anywhere on the internet without video lag.

I had a more expensive NVIDIA GPU in my system with otherwise state of the art hardware. The newest most power Ryzen 9 \ 5900 CPU, fast memory and a 750 watt power supply. The NVIDIA GPU ran like hot garbage on my Ubuntu system. Ubuntu has a nasty sepia color scheme that saturates the entire OS and everything in it. It is not only ugly but painful to look at due to my vision issues.

I did not know for sure at the time but, I hoped a new video card from someone other than NVIDIA might perform better. Turns out this AMD designed GPU got rid of the nasty sepia tint. This video card creates a simple un-tinted OS that is a pleasure to use. The card is not BIG and uses only the power supplied by the GPU slot.

The card has some energy saver garbage installed that turns the card off if you power down your monitor. I took a star off for the energy saver mess. There really are no other issues. This is a great card to use on a Linux\Ubuntu system that is not used for hard core gaming.

Reviews.title: Great for what it is
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2022
Reviews.text:
I recently built my first gaming pc in 20 years. I ordered everything but the graphics card, and when I went to research and price them... Whoa! Man have things changed in 20 years! Needless to say I needed something until I could afford a good graphics card. Enter MaxSun Radeon RX550. This card actually impressed me. Not only was I able to get my system up and running, I was also able to play a few of my favorite games, like BeamNG.drive. Granted, the settings were on Low and some on Medium, and the FPS wasn't optimal, but it was definitely playable.

While I wouldn't recommend this as a primary card for gaming, it makes a great backup.

And I was able to take full advantage of the Radeon technology in my monitor - was able to set it to 185mhz refresh rate too. Fortnite looks 1000 times better!

Reviews.title: Terrific Video Card

Reviews.title: Good Enough
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2022
Reviews.text:
My employer bought a stack of Dell 5080's (very basic) and I bought one from her. I loaded up the memory and changed to an SSD. It doesn't take much to elevate this. I also wanted to get a discrete video card and take the load off the onboard video. Saw this card. 4GB? At this price? In my case, it's overkill, but more is better, right? I counted on Amazon's liberal return policy and took the gamble. I changed to the low-profile bracket, ditching the VGA port and downloaded the latest NVIDIA drivers. I'm pleased to say this card and its 4GB are running two 27" monitors essentially straight from setup. I don't know why other reviews can't run more than one monitor, but I also don't know their level of expertise. I come from that 90's & 2000's group that went and got bits and pieces at Fry's and popped them into the computer case, learning by trial and error. I'm no expert, but I can get by.

There is absolutely nothing in the box other than the card and the low-profile bracket. You'll have to go to NVIDIA dot com to get your drivers. I disk or leaflet with minimal instructions wouldn't go amiss with some of the purchasers.

Anyway...good video card, reliable (so far) after four weeks, and I'm happy with my purchase.

Reviews.title: Doesn't work
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2022
Reviews.text:
I don't want to do any gaming, I wanted a cheap card that could drive a drive one VGA monitor with 1920x1200 and one HDMI monitor with 1440x2560.
There were no directions in the box, and almost nothing written on the box. The Amazon website had a lot more information than the box.
The Amazon website says that KAER offers 24-hour technical support, but doesn't say what the URL for that is and neither does the box. www.kaer.com is an air-conditioning company, and Google just turns up a ton of false hits.
When I installed the card and turned the CPU on, it only detected one monitor and was confused about it. Windows -> System -> Display says it was 1024x769 with no other options, but stuff that was supposed to be in the center of the screen was at the edge of the screen. Websites kept coming up where the buttons were off the bottom of the screen when the top of the window was at the top of the screen.
The colors were all wrong, too.
I figured it was a driver problem, so with great difficulty I went to the NVIDEA website and downloaded the driver for the NVIDEA Geforce GT 730 (the box says nothing about NVIDEA and there are no directions, I was just going by what the Amazon website said).
Installing the driver made no difference. I did it twice.
I give up. I'm sending this back to Amazon, never buying anything from KAER again.

Reviews.title: Works great
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2022
Reviews.text: I use this graphics card for X-Plane on an older Intel 4790 that only supports DDR-3 memory. The program demands a lot of video resources, which the GD-1030 supplies. I cannot run at the highest frame rates, but it runs quite well. I am very satisfied with this graphics card.

Reviews.title: A solution to a problem.
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
Reviews.text:
A family member had their monitor burn out and a 4K monitor was bought. Sadly, the built-in video card in the older computer was not strong enough to support the max resolution.

This video card did exactly that. And it is fine for a computer that is used for surfing, basic desktop work, etc. But once you want to watch a full-screen 4K video it struggles. Badly.
To be fair here, the 10-series were not built for 4K. But it needs to be said: it is one thing to do static work on 4K resolutions; once you go to a high-quality media display this is not the card you are looking for.

So this card does what it needs to do - and it will perform fine for most things in resolutions under 4k. It is affordable and available. But don't buy this one for high-quality gaming or intensive video or animation work.

Reviews.title: Probably was a return
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2022
Reviews.text: Some of the previous reviewers had opined that there cards might have been returns. I received an open box (no factory tape on the folds) and no documentation on the inside. No disk, manual, or anything for that matter other than the card. Obviously a return. Forewarned is forearmed and I had already gone to the Maxsun website and downloaded the latest drivers. I installed the card and, in fairness, works as advertised. The vendor just needs to ensure that the documentation is in every box. I also haven't registered it (no disk asking me to) but will do that on the website. Arrived on time.

Reviews.title: Calling all base model alien ware x51 users
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2021
Reviews.text: Okay so to start , can you run gears 5 on 4k absolutely not. Can you run in a stock Alienware x51 without upgrading your power brick and running extra power ? Absolutely yes! Fits right in slim designed case , total install time was 10 min if that. I have looked high and I've looked low for a form fitting card for the x51 without a massive power overhaul. This card is not what I call "gaming" ready but the price point should sell you that. Overall it's slim will definitely fit in a modular case and does the trick of you are looking to do anything that's graphic hungry. Minus of course Fortnite at 60fps consistent. The value is peek. The extra 2gb of room helps to. Hope this is your final review to read before pulling the trigger. I did , great product in an oversaturated market currently

Reviews.title: Perfect for the price in today's market!
Reviews.location-date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2022
Reviews.text: This GPU isn't the top of the line, but paired with my 60hz 2560x1600 HP monitor, it's given me crystal clear images with good FPS in Halo Infinite (@1366x768 for H.I. only), Kerbal Space Program, and Automation, the Car Company Tycoon Game. Though in Beam.NG, visual settings have to be set to Low for decent-good FPS. It keeps at a decent temperature (35-45°C) while being run at 100% consistently. If you're looking for a good GPU for 3D dense programs such as Second Life, this one is more then capable with the sacrifice of FPS (25-30 at High, 10-15 at Ultra graphics settings).
